ORDER IN Pending CasE
No. A-362. Ukrainian-American Bar Association, Inc., et al., Appli-
cants v. George P. Shultz, Secretary of State, et al. The application for
injunctive relief, or in the alternative to treat the application as a peti-
tion for writ of habeas corpus, presented to the Chief Justice and by
him referred to the Court is denied.



(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 1985
177
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.'
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 84-1852. Pennsylvania, Petitioner v. Benjamin Goldhammer. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania,
Eastern District. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is reversed and case remanded to the Supreme
Court of Pennsylvania for further consideration in light of United States
v. DiFrancesco, 449 U.S. 117 (1980). Justice Brennan dissents from
summary disposition and would vote to deny the petition. Dissenting
statement by Justice Marshall. Justice Blackmun would grant the peti-
tion and set the case for argument. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Stevens.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 85-485. John W. Gibson, Appellant v. Board of Attorneys Pro-
fessional Responsibility of Wisconsin. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of Wisconsin. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 85-497. In the matter of N. P., Appellant. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Minnesota. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI -SUMMARY DISPOSITION:
No. 85-5271. Samuel Lee Felder, Petitioner v. Alabama. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Alabama. The motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for
writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the Supreme Court of Alabama for further consideration
in light of Ake v. Oklahoma, 470 U.S. (1985).

178
TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 1985
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. —. Gilbert F. Barker, Jr., et al., Petitioners v. E. I. Dupont
de Nemours & Co., Inc., et al. The motion to direct the Clerk to file the
petition for writ of certiorari out-of-time is denied. Justice Powell took
no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. A-301. Banboye Stephen Mainsah, Applicant v. Immigration and
Naturalization Service. The application for stay of deportation ad-
dressed to Justice Marshall and referred to the Court is denied.
No. A-345. In Re Harry Toussaint Alexander. The application for
recall and stay of mandate presented to the Chief Justice and by him
referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-506. In the Matter of Disbarment of Phillip C. Daniels, Jr.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-509. In the Matter of Disbarment of Harry Toussaint Alexan-
der. It is ordered that Harry Toussaint Alexander, of Washington,
D.C., be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a
rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-510. In the Matter of Disbarment of John Cody. Disbarment
order entered.
No. D-514. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert Alan Lebovitz.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-517. In the Matter of Disbarment of William Devine Sabiston,
Jr. It having been reported to the Court that William Devine Sabiston,
Jr., has died, the Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on September
18, 1985, is hereby discharged.
No. 84–1279. Delaware, Petitioner v. Robert E. Van Arsdall. The
motion of respondent for divided argument is denied.
No. 84-2030. Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation, Appellant v.
New York State Liquor Authority. The motion of appellant to dispense
with printing the joint appendix is denied. Justice Brennan took no part
in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 84-6270. Johnny Green, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Agnes Mary
Mansour, Director, Michigan Department of Social Services. The mo-
tion of petitioners for leave to file a supplemental brief after argument
is granted.
No. 85-195. Icicle Seafoods, Inc., Petitioner v. Larry Worthington,
et al. The motion of petitioner to dispense with printing the joint appen-
dix is granted.

TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 1985
179
No. 85-246. United States, Petitioner v. Dwight Dion, Sr. The
motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that
Terry L. Pechota, Esquire, of Rapid City, South Dakota, is appointed
to serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 85-441. Lillian Roberts, Commissioner of Labor of the State of
New York, Appellant v. Burlington Industries, Inc.; and
No. 85-460. Irving Gilbert, et al., Appellants v. Burlington Indus-
tries, Inc. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in these cases
expressing the views of the United States.

of jurisdiction is postponed to the hearing of the case on the merits.

No. 84-6838. Phyllis A. Barrett, Petitioner v. United States Cus-
toms Service, et al. The motion of petitioner for reconsideration of the
order denying leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The order

Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied.

writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Mississippi denied. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins.

writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice White.
No. 85-46. David Allen Roeder, Petitioner v. Texas. The petition for
a writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas is denied.
Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall dissenting: Adhering to our views
that the death penalty is in all circumstances cruel and unusual punish-
ment prohibited by the Eight and Fourteenth Amendments, Gregg v.
Georgia, 428 U.S. 153, 227, 231 (1976), we would grant certiorari and

186
TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 1985
vacate the judgment below so that the court below can determine the
sentence, other than death, that may be appropriate.
No. 85-58. James Moran, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Pima County,
et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Arizona,
Division Two, denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice White.
No. 85-100. Michigan, Petitioner v. Clarence Carl Blackburn. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Michigan denied.
The Chief Justice and Justice White would grant certiorari.
No. 85-5448. Richard Lee Whitley, Petitioner v. Toni V. Bair, War-
den. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Virginia
denied. Dissenting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 18, 1985
195
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice White, Justice Marshall
Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist, and Justice
O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 85-216. Frank Roa, Jr., and Yvonne Jean Roa, individually and
as Guardians ad litem for Frank Joseph Roa, Appellants v. Lodi Medi-
cal Group, Inc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of California.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Jus-
tice Brennan and Justice White would note probable jurisdiction and set
the case for oral argument.
No. 85-342. Theodore Painter, Jr., Appellant v. Alaska. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of Alaska. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 85-5529. Lyle H. Prenzler, Appellant v. Dean Forwarding Com-
pany, Inc. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Fourth Ap-
pellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treat-
ing the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 85-5531. Gil Meyer, Appellant v. Oregon. Appeal from the Court
of Appeals of Oregon. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 85-522. Allied Bond and Collection Agency, Appellant v. Massa-
chusetts. Appeal from the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Jus-
tice Powell and Justice O'Connor would note probable jurisdiction and
set the case for oral argument.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 85-5113. William Richard Minor, Petitioner v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in

196
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 18, 1985
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light
of Dowling v. United States, 473 U.S. (1985).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-355. Ronald G. Cheeseman, et al., Applicants v. United
States. The application to vacate a stay entered by the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit presented to Justice Marshall
and by him referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-504. In the Matter of Disbarment of James Norman Howard.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-515. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jeffrey Marc Kanter. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-516. In the Matter of Disbarment of Raymond McKaba. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-531. In the Matter of Disbarment of Francisco M. Camacho. It
is ordered that Francisco M. Camacho, of Mukwonago, Wisconsin, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-532. In the Matter of Disbarment of Stephen Frank Hefner. It
is ordered that Stephen Frank Hefner, of Sherman, Texas, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 84–1244. Susan J. Davis, et al., Appellants v. Irwin C. Bande-
mer, et al. The appellants having reapplied for a stay in this case pend-
ing its final resolution in this Court and it appearing that all of the re-
quirements for the issuance of a stay are satisfied, the application is
granted and it is ordered that the judgment of the District Court for the
Southern District of Indiana is stayed until further order of the Court.
No. 84-1744. Thomas J. Henderson, Scott O. Thornton and Ruth
Freedman, Petitioners v. United States. The motion of petitioner Ruth
Freedman for leave to proceed further herein in forma pauperis is
granted. The motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is
ordered that Alex Reisman, Esquire, of San Francisco, California, is
appointed to serve as counsel for the petitioner Ruth Freedman in this
case.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 18, 1985
197
No. 84–1922. United States, Petitioner v. Hana Koecher. The motion
of the Solicitor General to dispense with printing the joint appendix is
granted.
No. 85-54. Library of Congress, et al., Petitioners v. Tommy Shaw.
The motion of the Solicitor General to dispense with printing the joint
appendix is granted.
No. 85-289. United States Department of Transportation, et al.,
Petitioners v. Paralyzed Veterans of America, et al. The motion of
the Solicitor General to dispense with printing the joint appendix is
granted.
No. 84-1993. John Hyde, Petitioner v. Bernard L. Van Wormer,
et al. The motion of the federal respondents for an award of damages
is granted, and damages are awarded to the federal respondents only in
the amount of $500 pursuant to this Court's Rule 49.2. The motion of
respondents, Inland Steel Company, et al., for award of damages is
granted, and damages in the amount of $500 are awarded pursuant to
this Court's Rule 49.2. The request of Inland Steel Company, et al. for
award of double costs pursuant to Rule 50.7 is denied. The motion of
petitioner for award of costs and fees is denied. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens join.
Dissenting statement by Justice Blackmun.
No. 85-552. Yosh Sakamoto, et al., Petitioners v. Duty Free Shop-
pers, Ltd., et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this
case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 85-616. Sharon Steel Corporation, Appellant v. City of Fair-
mont, West Virginia, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief
in this case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 85-556. Ralph Kemp, Warden, Petitioner v. Henry Arthur
Drake. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris is granted.
No. 85-5487. Michael Marnell Smith, Petitioner v. Allyn R. Sielaff,
Director, Virginia Department of Corrections. The motion for appoint-
ment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that J. Lloyd Snook, III,
Esquire, of Charlottesville, Virginia, is appointed to serve as counsel
for the petitioner in this case.
No. 85-5563. Matthew M. Fondel, Petitioner v. Ford Motor Com-
pany, et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris is denied. Petitioner is allowed until December 9, 1985, within
which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a
petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice

198
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 18, 1985
-
Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the rea-
sons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. (1983), we
would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the
merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.

OPINIONS
No. 84-1103. William Lloyd Hill, Petitioner v. A. L. Lockhart, Direc-
tor, Arkansas Department of Correction. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Opinion by Justice White
concurring in the judgment with whom Justice Stevens joins.
No. 84-489. Pennsylvania Bureau of Correction, Petitioner v. United
States Marshals Service, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1985
213
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 85-506. Peter A. Ascani, Sr., individually and on behalf of the
Estate of David Nathan Ascani, et al., Appellants v. Darrell Hughes,
et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 85-583. Patricia A. Fahey, Appellant v. James E. Beckley, et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Cir-
cuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 85-551. American Federation of Government Employees,
AFL-CIO, et al., Appellants v. Ronald W. Reagan, President of the
United States, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the District of Columbia. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-1815. Lynn M. Hoffman, Petitioner v. Eti-Quette Assaf Ltd.,
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of Sedima, S. P. R. L. v. Imrex Company, Inc., 473
U.S. (1985).
No. 85-5496. William Boyd Tucker, Petitioner v. Ralph Kemp, War-
den. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. The motion of National Legal Aid and
Defender Association, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is

214
MONDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1985
granted. The motion of Vivian O. Berger, et al. for leave to file a brief
as amici curiae is granted. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted.
The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in
light of Caldwell v. Mississippi, 472 U.S. (1985).
-
No. 85-5503. Billy Rogers, Petitioner v. Ohio. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Ohio. The motion of petitioner for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certio-
rari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the Supreme Court of Ohio for further consideration in light of Caldwell
v. Mississippi, 472 U.S. (1985).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-511. In the Matter of Disbarment of Eugene A. Stock. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-533. In the Matter of Disbarment of Levi W. Evans, III. It is
ordered that Levi W. Evans, III, of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 84-773. Michael Bender, et al., Petitioners v. Williamsport Area
School District, et al. The motion of respondents for leave to file a sup-
plemental brief after argument is granted.
No. 84-871. Louisiana Public Service Commission, Appellant v. Fed-
eral Communications Commission, et al.;
No. 84-889. California and Public Utilities Commission of California,
et al., Petitioners v. Federal Communications Commission and United
States;
,
No. 84-1054. Public Utilities Commission of Ohio, et al., Petitioners
v. Federal Communications Commission, et al.; and
No. 84–1069. Florida Public Service Commission, Petitioner v. Fed-
eral Communications Commission, et al. The motion of the Solicitor
General for divided argument is granted. Justice Powell and Justice
O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 84-902. Wardair Canada, Inc., Appellant v. Florida Department
of Revenue. The motion of appellant to dispense with printing the joint
appendix is granted.
No. 84-6646. Willie Lloyd Turner, Petitioner v. Allyn R. Sielaff,
Director, Virginia Department of Corrections. Further consideration of

MONDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1985
215
the motion of petitioner to strike ex parte affidavit is deferred to the
hearing of the case on the merits.
No. 85-202. Offshore Logistics, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Beth A.
Tallentire, et al. The motion of Sonat Offshore Drilling, Inc., et al. for
leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.
No. 85-615. California Department of Transportation, Petitioner v.
Naegele Outdoor Advertising Company of California, etc., et al.; and
No. 85-639. Desert Outdoor Advertising, Inc., Petitioner v. Naegele
Outdoor Advertising Company of California, Inc. The Solicitor General
is invited to file a brief in these cases expressing the views of the
United States.
No. 85-5189. Lamont Julius Mclaughlin, Petitioner v. United States.
The motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that
Stephen J. Cribari, Esquire, of Baltimore, Maryland, is appointed to
serve as counsel for the petitioner in this case.
No. 85-5688. Earl L. Jones, Petitioner v. American Postal Workers
Union Headquarters Local 6885, et al. The motion of petitioner for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until
December 23, 1985, within which to pay the docketing fee required by
Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the
Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall, dissenting:
For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S.
(1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without
reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
-
No. 85-521. Margaret M. Heckler, Secretary of Health and Human
Services, et al., Appellants v. Public Agencies Opposed to Social Secu-
rity Entrapment, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Eastern District of California. In this case probable jurisdiction
is noted.

with whom Justice Brennan joins.

Superintendent, Rahway State Prison, et al. On writ of certiorari to the

versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist.

Mansour, Director, Michigan Department of Social Services. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.

by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, and
Justice Stevens join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with whom
Justice Brennan and Justice Stevens join. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Blackmun with whom Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, and Justice
Stevens join.
No. 84-1240. Lake Coal Company, Inc., Petitioner v. Roberts &
Schaefer Company. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The motion of the parties requesting
the Court to decide the questions presented in the petition for writ of

238
TUESDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1985
certiorari despite complete settlement of the underlying causes of ac-
tion is denied. See DeFunis v. Odegaard, 416 U.S. 312 (1974). Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the United States District Court
for the Eastern District of Kentucky with instructions to dismiss the
cause as moot. Opinion per curiam announced by the Chief Justice.

FRIDAY, DECEMBER 6, 1985
241
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-440. Jose Moises Guzmon, Applicant v. Texas. The application
for stay of execution of the sentence of death scheduled for Monday,
December 9, 1985, presented to Justice White and by him referred to
the Court is granted pending the filing of a petition for a writ of certio-
rari on or before January 6, 1986. In the event the petition for a writ of
certiorari is filed by said date, this order is to continue pending the dis-
position of the petition for a writ of certiorari. Should the petition for a
writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates automatically. In the
event the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted, this stay shall con-
tinue pending the issuance of the mandate of this Court.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1985
243
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"It is my sad duty to announce that our distinguished colleague and
friend, Justice Potter Stewart, died Saturday, December 7, 1985, in
Hanover, New Hampshire.
Justice Stewart served as a Judge of the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit from 1954 to 1958 when he was appointed
to this Court to succeed Justice Harold Burton. He took office on Octo-
ber 14, 1958, and served as an Associate Justice for 23 years until his
retirement in 1981 at the close of the 1980 Term of Court. He had
served his country for four years in the United States Navy in World
War II.
His appointment to the Court of Appeals in 1954 came at the age of
39, making him the youngest Federal Judge in the country at that time.
His opinions on a wide range of subjects appear in nearly 100 volumes of
the United States Reports covering a period of great social, political
and economic development reflecting the turmoil, upheavals and
changes taking place throughout the world.
Those changes had a marked impact on the kinds of issues coming
into all courts including this Court. In meeting these issues in the
setting of the dramatic changes in the world at large, Justice Stewart
exhibited a steadiness of purpose, comprehension and grasp of contem-
porary law and its antecedents in the Common Law.
His work as a Justice rejected the popular labels and categorizations
of judges. Adhering to precedent he sought to resolve cases on narrow
grounds leaving related but unresolved issues to the future. He was
particularly concerned that the rights of privacy of person and home,
protected by the Fourth Amendment be observed by all levels of gov-
ernment. Few legal issues concerned him more than the protection of
the rights envisaged by those who drafted the Constitution and the Bill
of Rights.
We mourn Justice Stewart's passing but we will not forget the com-
radeship and friendship that overshadowed the inescapable differences
arising in the processes of resolving the difficult issues that find their
way to this Court.

244
MONDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1985
I speak for all members of the Court in expressing our profound sym-
pathy to Mrs. Stewart and her family.
In due course, the traditional memorial service of the Bar of this
Court and the Court will be conducted in this Chamber to pay our re-
spects more fully to Justice Stewart."
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 85-5685. David Hamilton, Appellant v. California. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of California. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-1736. Miguel Hijar, Superintendent, Federal Prison at
Boron, California v. James Robert Burrus. The judgment of the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States District Court for the Northern District
of California with instructions to vacate the injunction and to dismiss
the cause as moot.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-353. Alan Ernest, etc., Applicant v. United States Attorney
for the Southern District of Alabama, et al. The application for an
injunction or writ of habeas corpus addressed to Justice Rehnquist and
referred to the Court is denied. The motion to recuse Justice Powell is
denied.
No. D-523. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard Allison Gantt.
Richard Allison Gantt, of Greenville, South Carolina, having requested
to resign as a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his
name be stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before
the Bar of this Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on
October 15, 1985, is hereby discharged.
No. D-534. In the Matter of Disbarment of David I. Pesner. It is
ordered that David I. Pesner, of Spring Valley, New York, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1985
245
No. D-535. In the Matter of Disbarment of Salvatore L. Romano, Jr.
It is ordered that Salvatore L. Romano, Jr., of Providence, Rhode Is-
land, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 29, Original. Texas and New Mexico, Plaintiffs v. Colorado. The
stipulated motion for dismissal is granted and this cause is dismissed
with prejudice. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

Justice Stevens and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 84-732. Theodore Cleavinger, Marvin Marcadis, and Tom P.
Lockett, Petitioners v. David Saxner and Alfred Cain, Jr. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Rehnquist with whom the Chief Justice and Justice
White join.
No. 84-786. Maine, Petitioner v. Perley Moulton, Jr. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Judicial Court of Maine. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by the Chief Justice
with whom Justice White and Justice Rehnquist join, and with whom
Justice O'Connor joins as to Parts I and III.
No. 83-1807. Eastern Air Lines, Inc., Petitioner v. Robert F.
Mahfoud, etc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed by an equally divided
Court. Opinion per curiam announced by the Chief Justice. Justice
Brennan took no part in the decision of this case.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 16, 1985
263
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Rehnquist, and Justice
O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 85-636. Janice Marie Nyflot, Appellant v. Minnesota Commis-
sioner of Public Safety. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Minnesota.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
Dissenting opinion by Justice White with whom Justice Stevens joins.
No. 85-5686. Louis F. Gaines, Appellant v. Merchants National Bank
and Trust Company of Indianapolis. Appeal from the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 85-5761. Emma Rita Mihal, Appellant v. Harry Jaffe, Judge,
Cuyahoga County Court of Common Pleas. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Ohio. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari is denied.

It is ordered that Wesley Earl Kidwell, Jr., of Rockville, Maryland, be

264
MONDAY, DECEMBER 16, 1985
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

v. State Oil and Gas Board of Mississippi and Coastal Exploration, Inc.,
et al. The motion of appellee Coastal Exploration, Inc. for leave to file

of respondent for leave to file a supplemental brief after argument is
granted.
No. 84–1728. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, Peti-
tioner v. Federal Labor Relations Authority, et al. The motion of re-
spondent American Federation of Government Employees, AFL-CIO,
National Council of EEOC Locals, for divided argument is denied.

leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.

fort of Colorado, Inc. The motion of petitioners for leave to submit Rule
28.1 material under seal is granted. Justice Blackmun took no part in
the consideration or decision of this motion.

Quiller, et ux., etc.;

v. General Electric Credit Corporation; and

clays American/Credit, Inc. The Solicitor General is invited to
file a brief in these cases expressing the views of the United States.
Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of this
order.
No. 85-5487. Michael Marnell Smith, Petitioner v. Edward W. Mur-
ray, Acting Director, Virginia Department of Corrections. The motion
of New Jersey Department of the Public Advocate for leave to file a
brief as amicus curiae is granted.

cuit denied.

OPINION
No. 84-1023. United States, Petitioner v. Fernando
Fernando Rojas-
Contreras. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Opinion by
Justice Blackmun concurring in the judgment with whom Justice Bren-
nan joins.

(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, JANUARY 9, 1986
279
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
PETITION DENIED
No. 85-6155. James Terry Roach, Petitioner v. James Aiken, War-
den, et al. The application for stay of execution of the sentence of death
scheduled for Friday, January 10, 1986, presented to the Chief Justice
and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit
is denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice
Marshall joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Jus-
tice Brennan joins.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JANUARY 13, 1986
281
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 85-749. Michelle Marie W., a minor by and through her Guardian
Ad Litem Verle Williams, et al., Appellants v. Judith Anne Riley and
Ronald Bearley W. Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice
White and Justice Stevens would note probable jurisdiction and set the
case for oral argument.
No. 85-773. Atlantic Richfield Company, et al., Appellants v.
Alaska, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Alaska. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. The Chief Justice,
Justice White and Justice Stevens would note probable jurisdiction and
set the case for oral argument. Justice Powell took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this case.
No. 85-787. Russell D. Daves, Appellant v. State Bar of Texas.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Texas, Seventh Supreme Judicial
District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 85-5455. Michael M. Garcia, aka Michael M. Travalino, Appel-
lant v. Charles Dixon, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 85-5853. Merle L. Royse, Appellant v. United States, et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Western District
of Washington. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . Rudy J. Ramirez, Petitioner v. California. The motion to
permit petitioner to proceed in forma pauperis without submitting an
affidavit of indigency is denied.

282
MONDAY, JANUARY 13, 1986
No. A-436. Manuel Nicholas Diaz, Applicant v. United States. The
application for release on bail pending trial addressed to Justice
Brennan and referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-525. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert Edward Phelps,
Jr. Robert Edward Phelps, Jr., of Houston, Texas, having requested
to resign as a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his
name be stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before
the Bar of this Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on
October 21, 1985, is hereby discharged.
No. D-528. In the Matter of Disbarment of Tom L. Larkin. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-530. In the Matter of Disbarment of Scott Thomas Siegfried.
Scott Thomas Siegfried, of Wadsworth, Ohio, having requested to re-
sign as a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be
stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar
of this Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on November
4, 1985, is hereby discharged.
No. D-538. In the Matter of Disbarment of William V. Vetter. It is
ordered that William V. Vetter, of Tacoma, Washington, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-539. In the Matter of Disbarment of Donald H. Mueller. It is
ordered that Donald H. Mueller, of Milwaukee, Wisconsin, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-540. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard G. Chosid. It is
ordered that Richard G. Chosid, of Bloomfield Hills, Michigan, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-541. In the Matter of Disbarment of Calvin Roosevelt Bould-
ing. It is ordered that Calvin Roosevelt Boulding, of Houston, Texas,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 84, Original. United States of America, Plaintiff v. State of
Alaska. The application of the Special Master for award of interim com-
pensation is granted and the is awarded interim compensation in the

MONDAY, JANUARY 13, 1986
283
amount of $75,000 to be paid by the State of Alaska and the United
States in equal portions.
No. 104, Original. State of New Jersey, Plaintiff v. State of Nevada,
The Nevada Public Service Commission and the City of Las Vegas,
Nevada. It is ordered that the Honorable Wade H. McCree, Jr., of Ann
Arbor, Michigan, is appointed Special Master in this case with author-
ity to fix the time and conditions for the filing of additional pleadings
and to direct subsequent proceedings, and the authority to summon
witnesses, issue subpoenas, and take such evidence as may be intro-
duced and such as he may deem necessary to call for. The Master is
directed to submit such reports as he may deem appropriate.
The Master shall be allowed his actual expenses. The allowances to
him, the compensation paid to his technical, stenographic and and cleri-
cal assistants, the cost of printing his report, and all other proper
expenses shall be charged against and be borne by the parties in such
proportion as the Court may hereafter direct.
It is further ordered that if the position of Special Master in this case
becomes vacant during a recess of the Court, the Chief Justice shall
have authority to make a new designation which shall have the same
effect as if originally made by the Court.
The motion of City of Las Vegas to be dismissed as a party defendant
is referred to the Special Master.
No. 84–1076. Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation, Appellant
v. State Oil and Gas Board of Mississippi and Coastal Exploration, Inc.,
et al. The motion of appellant for leave to file a supplemental brief after
argument is granted.
No. 84–1545. Miller-Wohl Company, Inc., Appellant v. Commis-
sioner of Labor and Industry of Montana and Tamara L. Buley. The
motion of Chamber of Commerce of the United States for leave to file a
brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Equal Employment
Advisory Council for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
The motion of American Civil Liberties Union, et al. for leave to file a
brief as amici curiae is granted.
No. 84-1656. Local 28 of the Sheet Metal Workers' International
Association and Local 28 Joint Apprenticeship Committee, Petitioners
v. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, et al. The motion of
the Solicitor General for divided argument and for additional time for
oral argument is denied. The motion of North Carolina Association of
Black Lawyers for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus
curiae, for divided argument and for additional time for oral argument,

284
MONDAY, JANUARY 13, 1986
or in the alternative, for appointment of counsel to brief and argue in
support of judgment below, as amicus curiae, is denied.
No. 84-1667. Bethel School District No. 403, et al., Petitioners v.
Matthew N. Fraser, a Minor and E. L. Fraser, Guardian Ad Litem.
The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral
argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is denied.
No. 84–1726. East River Steamship Corp., et al., Petitioners v.
Transamerica Delaval Inc. The motion of Pott Industries Inc. for leave
to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Product Liabil-
ity Advisory Council, Inc., et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae
is granted. The motion of Ingram River Equipment, Inc. for leave to
file a brief as amicus curiae is denied.

brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Atlantic City Casino
Association for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The

to file a brief as amici curiae granted.

MONDAY, JANUARY 13, 1986
No. 85-641. Robert C. Hatch, et al., Petitioners v. Reliance In-
surance Company. The motion of respondent for award of damages is
granted and damages in the amount of $500 are awarded pursuant to
this Court's Rule 49.2. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice
Blackmun, and Justice Stevens dissent.
No. 85-736. Ralph Kemp, Warden, Petitioner v. Joseph Thomas. The
motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
No. 85-5821. Alex Melvin Wade, Jr., Petitioner v. United States.
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
denied. Petitioner is allowed until February 3, 1986, within which to
pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in
compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan and
Justice Marshall, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v.
Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. (1983), we would deny the petition for
writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed
in forma pauperis.

No. 85-5989. James Robert Horan, Petitioner v. United States. The

Court is denied.

No. 85-660. Colorado, Petitioner v. Francis Barry Connelly. The mo-
tion of Duane Woodard, Attorney General of of Colorado, et al. for
leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. The motion of respond-
ent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for
writ of to the Supreme Court of Colorado is granted. In addition to the
question presented by the petition for writ of certiorari, the parties are
requested to brief and argue the following question: Did respondent's
mental condition render his waiver of Miranda rights ineffective? The
application for stay, presented to Justice White and by him referred to
the Court, is granted pending the issuance of the mandate of this Court.
Memorandum by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Stevens joins.

ORAL ARGUMENTS
No. 84-1865. A. L. Lockhart, Director, Arkansas Department of
Correction, Petitioner v. Ardia V. McCree. Argued by Mr. John Steven
Clark for the petitioner and by Mr. Samuel R. Gross for the re-
spondent.
No. 85-5319. Willie Jasper Darden, Petitioner v. Louie L. Wain-
wright, Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. Argued by
Mr. Robert A. Harper, Jr., for the petitioner and by Mr. Richard W.
Prospect for the respondent.
No. 84-871. Louisiana Public Service Commission, Appellant v. Fed-
eral Communications Commission, et al;
No. 84-889. California and Public Utilities Commission of California,
et al., Petitioners v. Federal Communications Commission and United
States;
No. 84-1054. Public Utilities Commission of Ohio, et al., Petitioners
v. Federal Communications Commission, et al.; and
No. 84-1069. Florida Public Service Commission, Petitioner v. Fed-
eral Communications Commission, et al. Argued by Mr. Lawrence G.
Malone for the appellant and petitioners, by Mr. Solicitor General
Charles Fried for the federal appellees and respondents, and by
Mr. Michael Boudine for the respondents AT&T and former Bell Sys-
tem Operating Companies.
No. 84-1362. Public Service Commission of Maryland, Petitioner v.
Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company of Maryland. Argued by
Mr. Kirk J. Emge for the petitioner, by Mr. D. Michael Stroud for the
respondent, and by Mr. Jack D. Smith for the Federal Communication
Commission as amicus curiae in support of the respondent, by special
leave of Court.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, JANUARY 14, 1986
321
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 84-1480. Louie L. Wainwright, Secretary, Florida Department
of Corrections, Petitioner v. David Wayne Greenfield. On writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Opinion by Justice
Rehnquist concurring in the result with whom the Chief Justice joins.
No. 84-836. Daniel Vasquez, Warden, Petitioner v. Booker T.
Hillery, Jr. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Marshall.
Opinion by Justice O'Connor concurring in the judgment. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Powell with whom the Chief Justice and Justice
Rehnquist join.
No. 84-1144. United States, Petitioner v. John Von Newmann. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment reversed. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Concurring
opinion by the Chief Justice. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in
the judgment.
ORAL ARGUMENTS
No. 84-780. Otis R. Bowen, Secretary of Health and Human Serv-
ices, et al., Appellants v. Stephen J. Roy, et al. Argued by Mr. Kenneth
S. Geller for the appellants and by Mr. Gary S. Gildn for the appellees.
No. 84–1097. S. Simcha Goldman, Petitioner v. Caspar W. Weinber-
ger, Secretary of Defense, et al. Argued by Mr. Nathan Lewin for the
petitioner and by Ms. Kathryn A. Oberly for the respondents.
No. 84-1479. R. H. Kuhlman, Superintendent, Sullivan Correctional
Facility, Petitioner v. Joseph Allan Wilson. Argued by Mr. Steven R.
Kartagener for the petitioner and by Mr. Philip S. Weber for the
respondent.
No. 84-1606. Terrance Holbrook, Superintendent, Massachusetts
Correctional Institution, Norfolk, Massachusetts, et al., Petitioners v.

322
TUESDAY, JANUARY 14, 1986
Charles Flynn. Argued by Mr. Thomas More Dickinson for the peti-
tioner and by Mr. George Kannar for the respondent.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, JANUARY 21, 1986
325
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 85-714. Texas, et al., Appellants v. United States. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the Western District of Texas. The
judgment is affirmed.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-1706. Clement J. Pacyna, Petitioner v. John O. Marsh, Jr.,
Secretary of the Army. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the Court of Appeals to transfer the case pursuant to 28 U.S. Sec.
1631 to the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. See
28 U.S.C. Sec. 1295(a)(2).
No. 84-1750. Loy Ree B. Marlowe Ballam, Petitioner v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
Court of Appeals to transfer the case pursuant to 28 U.S.C. Sec. 1631
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. See 28
U.S.C. Sec. 1295(a)(2).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-483. Thomas L. Schuchman and Terry Lynn Schuchman, Ap-
plicants v. United States. The application for stay addressed to Justice
Brennan and referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-522. In the Matter of Disbarment of James Raymond Kamin-
sky. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-532. In the Matter of Disbarment of Stephen Frank Hefner.
Disbarment order entered.

326
TUESDAY, JANUARY 21, 1986
No. D-536. In the Matter of Disbarment of Lee Gilson Lovett. It is
ordered that Lee Gilson Lovett, of Washington, D.C., be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-542. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert William Bowles,
Jr. It is ordered that Robert William Bowles, Jr., of Orlando, Florida,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-543. In the Matter of Disbarment of Riner Ernest Deglow. It
is ordered that Riner Ernest Deglow, of Spokane, Washington, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 84-902. Wardair Canada, Inc., Appellant v. Florida Department
of Revenue. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate
in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted.
The motion of Aer Lingus, et al. for leave to participate in oral argu-
ment as amici curiae, for divided argument and for additional time for
oral argument is denied.
No. 84-1903. Posadas de Puerto Rico Associates, dba Condado Holi-
day Inn, Appellant v. Tourism Company of Puerto Rico. The motion of
Association of National Advertisers, Inc. for leave to file a brief as
amicus curiae is granted.
No. 84-2030. Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation, Appellant v.
New York State Liquor Authority. The motion of Wine and Spirits
Wholesalers of America, Inc. for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted. Justice Brennan took no part in the consideration or decision
of this motion.
No. 85-21. Square D Company and Big D Building Supply Corp.,
Petitioners v. Niagara Frontier Tariff Bureau, Inc., et al. The motion of
Association of American Railroads for leave to file a brief as amicus cu-
riae is granted. The motion of American Information Technologies
Corp., et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. The
motion of National Motor Freight Traffic Association, Inc., et al. for
leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.
No. 85–93. P. E. Bazemore, et al., Petitioners v. William C. Friday,

to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.

granted. The motion of Wisconsin Bell, Inc. for leave to file a brief as

Programmers, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.

No. 85-5404. Terry B. Allen, Petitioner v. Illinois. The motion of
Mental Health Information Service, Second Judicial Department, for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.

OPINIONS
No. 84-5872. Roy E. Daniels, Petitioner v. Andrew Williams. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Statement
by Justice Blackmun concurring in the judgment in this case. Opinion
by Justice Stevens concurring in the judgment in this case and in
No. 84-6470, post. Justice Marshall concurs in the result.
No. 84-6470. Robert Davidson, Petitioner v. Joseph Cannon, et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Stevens in this case and in No. 84-5872, ante.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Blackmun with whom Justice Marshall joins.
No. 84-1361. United States, Petitioner v. Kenneth Moses Loud
Hawk, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Marshall with whom Justice Brennan, Justice Blackmun and Justice
Stevens join.

ORAL ARGUMENTS
No. 84-1725. United States, Petitioner v. City of Fulton, et al.
Argued by Mr. Andrew J. Pincus for the petitioner and by Mr. Charles
F. Wheatley, Jr., for the respondents.
No. 84-1737. United States, Petitioner v. American College of Physi-
cians. Argued by Mr. Albert G. Lauber, Jr., for the petitioner and by
Mr. John B. Huffaker for the respondents.
No. 84-1554. Edward W. Murray, Acting Director, Virginia Depart-
ment of Corrections, Petitioner v. Clifford W. Carrier. Argued by
Mr. Jerry P. Slonaker for the petitioner, by Mr. Andrew L. Frey for
the United States, as amicus curiae, in support of the petitioner, by
special leave of Court, and by Mr. Sherman L. Cohn for the
respondent.
No. 84–1726. East River Steamship Corp., et al., Petitioners v.
Transamerica Delaval Inc. Argued by Mr. Thomas E. Durkin, Jr., for
the petitioners and by Mr. Robert E. Smith for the respondent.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.



(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 22, 1986
341
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 84-1076. Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation, Appellant
v. State Oil and Gas Board of Mississippi and Coastal Exploration, Inc.,
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Mississippi. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Supreme Court for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist with whom Justice
Powell, Justice Stevens and Justice O'Connor join.
No. 84-1236. Donald A. Cabana, Superintendent, Mississippi State
Penitentiary, et al., Petitioners v. Crawford Bullock, Jr. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The
judgment of the Court of Appeals is modified in part and the case is
remanded to that court for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Concurring opinion by
the Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom Justice Brennan and Justice
Marshall join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice
Brennan joins.
No. 84–1274. Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System,
Petitioner v. Dimension Financial Corporation, et al. On writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judg-
ment affirmed. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Justice White took no part
in the consideration or decision of this case.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JANUARY 27, 1986
343
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Justice Brennan, Justice White, Justice Marshall, Justice
Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, and
Justice O'Connor.
Justice Brennan said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by me, filed with the
Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 85-616. Sharon Steel Corporation, Appellant v. City of Fair-
mont, West Virginia, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Appeals
of West Virginia. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial fed-
eral question. Justice Brennan, Justice White and Justice Blackmun
would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral argument.
No. 85-871. Albert T. Willardo, Appellant v. Indiana. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of Indiana. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 85-967. Robert T. Smith, et ux., Appellants v. United States,
et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh
Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 85-5786. Henry Davis, Appellant v. First State Bank, etc.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 85-193. U.S. Trust Corporation, Petitioner v. Board of Gover-
nors of the Federal Reserve System, et al. On petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit.
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated
and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in light of Board of Gover-
nors of the Federal Reserve System v. Dimension Financial Corpora-
tion, 474 U.S. (1986).
-

344
MONDAY, JANUARY 27, 1986
No. 85-833. Chula Vista City School District, et al., Petitioners v.
William J. Bennett, Secretary, United States Department of Educa-
tion. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit to transfer the
case pursuant to 28 U.S.C. 1631 to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Federal Circuit. See 28 U.S.C. 1295(a)(2).
-

OPINIONS
No. 84-1616. Parsons Steel, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. First Alabama
Bank and Edward Herbert. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist.
No. 84-801. Midlantic National Bank, Petitioner v. New Jersey
Department of Environmental Protection; and
No. 84-805. Thomas J. O'Neill, Trustee in Bankruptcy of Quanta
Resources Corporation, Debtor, Petitioner v. City of New York, et al.;
and Thomas J. O'Neill, Trustee in Bankruptcy of Quanta Resources
Corporation, Debtor, Petitioner v. New Jersey Department of Envi-
ronmental Protection. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgments affirmed. Opinion by Jus-
tice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist with whom the
Chief Justice, Justice White and Justice O'Connor join.
No. 84-1070. Larry Witters, Petitioner v. Washington Department
of Services for the Blind. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Washington. Judgment reversed and cause remanded to the Supreme
Court for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this

MONDAY, JANUARY 27, 1986
357
Court. Opinion by Justice Marshall. Concurring opinion by Justice
White. Concurring opinion by Justice Powell with whom the Chief Jus-
tice and Justice Rehnquist join. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concurring
in the judgment and concurring in part.
No. 84-744. United States, Petitioner v. James C. Lane and Dennis
R. Lane; and
No. 84-963. James C. Lane and Dennis R. Lane, Petitioners v.
United States. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed in part, affirmed in
part and cause remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by the Chief
Justice announced by Justice Brennan. Opinion by Justice Brennan con-
curring in part and dissenting in part with whom Justice Blackmun
joins. Opinion by Justice Stevens dissenting in No. 84-744 and concur-
ring in No. 84-963 with whom Justice Marshall joins.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1986
359
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-593. John William Rook, Applicant v. Nathan A. Rice, War-
den. The application for stay of execution of the sentence of death
scheduled for Friday, February 14, 1986, presented to the Chief Justice
and by him referred to the Court, is granted pending the timely filing
and disposition by this Court of a petition for writ of certiorari. Should
the petition for a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates auto-
matically. In the event the petition for writ of certiorari is granted, this
stay shall continue pending the sending down of the judgement of this
Court.



(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 14, 1986
361
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-622. Edward Dean Kennedy, Applicant v. Louie L. Wain-
wright, Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections, et al. The appli-
cation for stay of execution of the sentence of death scheduled for Tues-
day, February 18, 1986, presented to Justice Powell and by him.
referred to the Court, is granted pending the timely filing and dispo-
sition by this Court of a petition for a writ of certiorari. Should the peti-
tion for a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates automati-
cally. In the event the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted, this
stay shall continue pending the issuance of the mandate of this Court.
Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of this
application.



(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 21, 1986
363
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 85-6372. Bobby James Moore, Petitioner v. Texas. The applica-
tion for stay of execution of the sentence of death presented to Justice
White and by him referred to the Court is denied. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the is denied. Dissenting statement by Justice Brennan
and Justice Marshall. Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens would
grant the application for stay.

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1986
365
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 85-182. Northwest Central Pipeline Corporation, et al., Appel-
lants v. Corporation Commission of Kansas, et al. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Kansas. The judgment is vacated and the case is re-
manded to the Supreme Court of Kansas for further consideration in
light of Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation v. State Oil and
Gas Board of Mississippi, 474 U.S. (1986).
-
No. 85-979. M. Francis Svendrowski, Appellant v. Missouri. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of Missouri, Eastern District. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 85-1080. San Diego Gas & Electric Company, Appellant v. Pub-
lic Utilities Commission of California. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of California. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 85-1091. Andrew Leoni and Houston Slate, Appellants v. State
Bar of California. Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 85-1232. Chris Stamos, etc., et al., Appellant v. Spring Branch
Independent School District, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Texas. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 85-1035. Crocker National Bank, Appellant v. Paul Perdue.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction.
No. 85-1040. Bruno Paul Kerner, Appellant v. Judges of the Wor-
cester Probate Court, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of
Appeals for the First Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.

366
MONDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1986
No. 85-1113. L. Chester Carter, Appellant v. Virginia. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Virginia. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 85-5931. Thomas Dyson, Appellant v. Texas. Appeal from the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 85-5947. Steve Stevenson, Appellant v. Legal Aid Society of
Hawaii. Appeal from the Intermediate Court of Appeals of Hawaii. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 85-6001. John A. Dooley, Appellant v. Todd E. Belcher. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Montgomery County. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 85-6002. John A. Dooley, Appellant v. Federal Home Loan
Mortgage Corporation, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio,
Montgomery County. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 85-1050. Jack F. Trahan, Appellant v. Emma J. Trahan. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of Texas, Third Supreme Judicial District.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Jus-
tice White would postpone jurisdiction to the hearing of the case on the
merits.
No. 85–1090. William H. Hudnut, III, Mayor, City of Indianapolis,
Indiana, et al., Appellants v. American Booksellers Association, Inc.,
et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit. The judgment is affirmed. The Chief Justice, Justice Rehnquist
and Justice O'Connor would note probable jurisdiction and set the case
for oral argument.
No. 85-5650. William H. X. Taylor, Appellant v. Carl Robinson,
Warden. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Connecticut. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice White,
Justice Powell and Justice O'Connor would note probable jurisdiction
and set the case for oral argument.

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1986
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
367
No. 84-1237. Morris L. Thigpen, Commissioner, Mississippi Depart-
ment of Corrections, et al., Petitioners v. Larry Jones. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma paupe-
ris is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of
Cabana v. Bullock, 474 U.S.—(1986).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES

Opportunity Commission. The motion of petitioners to direct the Clerk
to file a petition for writ of certiorari that does not comply with the
Rules of the Court is denied.

The motion of petitioner to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of
certiorari out-of-time and for relief from the requirement of Rule 28.2 is
denied.

No. . Anthony Vessichio, Petitioner v. Connecticut. The motion
of petitioner to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari
that does not comply with the Rules of the Court is denied.
No. D-445. In the Matter of Disbarment of John G. Nicholas. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-524. In the Matter of Disbarment of R. Michael Wetherbee.
Disbarment order entered. Justice Stevens dissents.
No. D-535. In the Matter of Disbarment of Salvatore L. Romano, Jr.
Salvatore L. Romano, Jr., of Providence, Rhode Island, having re-
quested to resign as a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered
that his name be stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to prac-
tice before the Bar of this Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore
issued on December 9, 1985, is hereby discharged.
No. D-544. In the Matter of Disbarment of Kenneth L. Tilley. It is
ordered that Kenneth L. Tilley, of Houston, Texas, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-545. In the Matter of Disbarment of David A. Willis. It is
ordered that David A. Willis, of Valparaiso, Indiana, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable

368
MONDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1986
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-546. In the Matter of Disbarment of Irving A. August. It is
ordered that Irving A. August, of Birmingham, Michigan, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

No. 85-6233. John Shewchun, Petitioner v. United States. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Petitioner is allowed until March 17, 1986, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice
Marshall, Justice Blackmun, and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the
reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983),
we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the
merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.

granted.

f

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1986
399
gia is denied. Justice Brennan, dissenting: Adhering to my view that
the death penalty is in all circumstances cruel and unusual punishment
prohibited by the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments, Gregg v. Geor-
gia, 428 U.S. 153, 227 (1976), I would grant certiorari and vacate the
death sentence in this case. Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun
would grant the petition for a writ of certiorari, vacate the judgment
and remand to the case to the Supreme Court of Georgia for further
consideration in light of Caldwell v. Mississippi, 472 U.S. (1985).
COMMON LAW CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 85-851. In Re Gary Carson, Petitioner. The petition for writ of
common law certiorari and/or mandamus is denied.
HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 85-6142. In Re Darnell Johnson, Petitioner. The petition for writ
of habeas corpus is denied.
MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 85-5921. In Re Myron Glenn Murphy, Petitioner; and
No. 85-6090. In Re Douglas Braaten, Petitioner. The petitions for
writs of mandamus are denied.
No. 85-5971. In Re Robert Martin Barritt, Petitioner. The petition
for writ of mandamus and/or prohibition is denied.
PROHIBITION DENIED
No. 85-6141. In Re Arthur K. Green, Jr., Petitioner. The petition for
a writ of prohibition and/or mandamus is denied.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 84–1855. Loras L. Steines, Petitioner v. The Rock Island Arse-
nal Department of Army & Constituents;
No. 84-6051. Stanley E. Allen, Petitioner v. Georgia;
No. 85-654. Seymour Allan Hurvitz, Petitioner v. Division of Medical
Quality, Board of Medical Quality Assurance, Department of Consumer
Affairs of California;

Mercante Grancolombiana, S. A. and Grancolombiana New York, Inc.;

et al.;

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1986
415
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 84-1181. New York, Petitioner v. Benigno Class. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the Court of Appeals of New York. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings not in-
consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor.
Concurring opinion by Justice Powell with whom the Chief Justice
joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Mar-
shall and Justice Stevens join. Dissenting opinion by Justice White with
whom Justice Stevens joins.
No. 35, Original. United States of America, Plaintiff v. States.
of Maine, New Hampshire, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, New York,
New Jersey, Delaware, Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina, South
Carolina, Georgia and Florida. On Exception to the Report of the Spe-
cial Master. Exception of Massachusetts to Report of Special Master
overruled. Parties are directed to prepare and submit a decree con-
forming to the recommendations of the Special Master. Opinion by Jus-
tice Stevens. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this case.
No. 84–1360. City of Renton, et al., Appellants v. Playtime Theatres,
Inc., et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of.
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Justice Blackmun concurs in the
result. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Mar-
shall joins.
No. 84-1640. United States, Petitioner v. Marshall Mechanik, et al.;
No. 84-1700. Jerome Otto Lill, Petitioner v. United States; and
No. 84-1704. Marshall Mechanik, aka Michael Patrick Flanagan,
Petitioner v. United States. On writs of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed in part and
affirmed in part and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Rehnquist. Concurring opinion by the Chief Justice. Opinion by

416
TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1986
Justice O'Connor concurring in the judgment with whom Justice Bren-
nan and Justice Blackmun join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall.
No. 84–1044. Pacific Gas and Electric Company, Appellant v. Public
Utilities Commission of California, et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of California. The order of the Supreme Court of California va-
cated and case remanded to the Supreme Court of California for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of the Court. Justice Pow-
ell announced the judgment of the Court and delivered and opinion in
which the Chief Justice, Justice Brennan and Justice O'Connor join.
Concurring opinion by the Chief Justice. Opinion by Justice Marshall
concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist
with whom Justice White and Justice Stevens join as to Part I. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice Stevens. Justice Blackmun took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 84–1922. United States, Petitioner v. Hana Koecher. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
Judgment of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit
vacated and case remanded to the United States District Court for the
Southern District of New York with instructions to dismiss the cause as
moot. Opinion per curiam announced by the Chief Justice.

No. 85-195. Icicle Seafoods, Inc., Petitioner v. Larry Worthington,
et al. Argued by Mr. Clemens H. Barnes for the petitioner and by Mr.
Carson F. Eller for the respondents.

WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1986

419
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 85-6276. Theodore Robert Bundy, Petitioner v. Florida. The
application for stay of execution of the sentence of death, scheduled for
Tuesday, March 4, 1986, presented to Justice Powell and by him re-
ferred to the Court, is granted pending the disposition by this Court of
the petition for a writ of certiorari. Should the petition for a writ of cer-
tiorari be denied, this stay terminates automatically. In the event the
petition for a writ of certiorari is granted, this stay shall continue pend-
ing the issuance of the mandate of this Court. The motion for leave to
supplement the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted. The supple-
ment is to be filed on or before March 28, 1986. A response to the sup-
plement shall be filed on or before April 11, 1986. The motion to defer
consideration of the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted pending
receipt of the supplement to the petition and the response thereto.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-653. Aubrey Dennis Adams, Applicant v. Louie L. Wain-
wright, Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections, et al. The appli-
cation for stay of execution of the sentence of death presented to Justice
Powell and by him referred to the Court is denied. Dissenting state-
ment by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall. Justice Blackmun and
Justice Stevens would grant the application for stay.

MONDAY, MARCH 3, 1986
