SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 85-987. Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority, Appel-
lant v. Amalgamated Transit Union International, AFL-CIO, et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Co-
lumbia Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 85-1116. City of Whittier, et al., Appellants v. Walnut Proper-
ties, Inc., et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of City of Renton v. Playtime Theatres, Inc., 475 U.S.
(1986).
No. 85-6026. Jeffrey Curtis Names, Appellant v. California. Appeal
from the Court of Appeal of California, Sixth Appellate District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 85-6144. Ralph G. Acuff, Appellant v. Lola Henry, et al. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Texas. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.

Inc. The motion of petitioner, seeking leave to proceed as a seaman, to
be relieved of printing the petition for writ of certiorari and the petition
for writ of mandamus in compliance with Rule 33 is denied. Justice
Stevens would grant the motion.

sylvania. The motion of National District Attorneys Association, et al.
for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. The motion of the

curiae and for divided argument is granted.

Appellant v. Republican Party of Connecticut, et al. The motion of
appellant to schedule oral argument during April Session is denied. Jus-

motion.

tion, et al. The motion of respondent James River Corporation for dam-
ages and fees is denied.

motion of the Solicitor General to defer consideration of the petition for
a writ of certiorari is granted.
No. 85-1258. Donald E. Brown, et al., Petitioners v. Kerr-McGee
Chemical Corporation. The motion of respondent to expedite consider-
ation of the petition for certiorari is denied.
No. 85-1429. American General Life and Accident Insurance Com-
pany, Appellant v. Carolyn Miller and Marvin Ramsey Miller, Sr. The
application for stay pending appeal addressed to Justice Powell and
referred to the Court is denied. Justice Blackmun dissents.
No. 85-6033. Anil M. Shah, Petitioner v. Kern County, California,
et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
denied. Petitioner is allowed until March 24, 1986, within which to pay
the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in
compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan,
Justice Marshall, and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons.
expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would

MONDAY, MARCH 3, 1986
427
deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of
the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.

tendent, Oregon State Penitentiary, et al., Petitioners v. Gerald
Albers. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Marshall with whom Justice Brennan, Justice Blackmun and Justice
Stevens join.

CIO, et al., Petitioners v. Annie Lee Hudson, et al. On writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.

Justice White with whom the Chief Justice joins.

THURSDAY, MARCH 6, 1986

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,

ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 85-6448. Aubrey D. Adams, Petitioner v. Louie L. Wainwright,
Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections, et al. The order of Feb-
ruary 28, 1986 is vacated. The application for stay of execution of the
sentence of death presented to Justice Powell and by him referred to
the Court, is granted until March 25, 1986, or until the disposition by
this Court of the petition for a writ of certiorari, whichever is earlier,
unless otherwise extended by the Court. Justice Rehnquist and Justice
O'Connor would deny the application for stay.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 10, 1986
449
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist, and
Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 85-353. Michigan Diversified Business Products, Inc., et al.,
Appellants v. City of Warren, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals
of Michigan. The appeal is dismissed for want of a properly presented
federal question. Justice Stevens would note probable jurisdiction and
set the case for oral argument. Justice Brennan took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this case.
No. 85-1185. Robert Wheaton, Appellant v. City of Oklahoma City,
et al. Appeal from the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice
Brennan took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 85-1211. Kondian R. Rajaram, Appellant v. A. S. Abell Publish-
ing Company. Appeal from the Court of Special Appeals of Maryland.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied. Justice Brennan took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this case.
No. 85-6206. Maria Luisa Costell Gaydos, Appellant v. June Stre-
lecki, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari is denied. Justice Brennan took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this case.
CERTIORARI
SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 85-298. John F. Connolly, Petitioner v. Andrew K. Burt. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth
Circuit. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit with directions
that it instruct the United States District Court for the District of Colo-

450
MONDAY, MARCH 10, 1986
rado to dismiss the complaint as moot. Justice Brennan took no part in
the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 85-198. Sandra Abernathy, et al., Petitioners v. San Jose Teach-
ers Association. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court
of California. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the Supreme Court of Cali-
fornia for further consideration in light of Chicago Teachers Union,
Local No. 1, AFT, AFL-CIO v. Hudson, 475 U.S. (1986). Justice
Brennan took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
-
No. . Elmwood-Utica Houses, Inc., Petitioner v. Buffalo Sewer
Authority. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of
certiorari out-of-time is denied. Justice Brennan took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this motion.
No. D-547. In the Matter of Disbarment of R. Jack Magruder, III. It
is ordered that R. Jack Magruder, III, of Little Rock, Arkansas, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court. Justice
Brennan took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 85-701. Federal Election Commission, Appellant v. Massachu-
setts Citizens for Life, Inc. The motion of Common Cause for leave to
file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. Justice Brennan took no part in
the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 85-782. Immigration and Naturalization Service, Petitioner v.
Luz Marina Cardoza-Fonseca. The motion of the Solicitor General to
dispense with printing the joint appendix is granted. Justice Brennan
took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 85-6124. Lawrence Edward Johnson, Jr., Petitioner v. United
States. The motion of petitioner to consolidate this case with
No. 85-5189, McLaughlin v. United States is denied. Justice Brennan
took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 85-6333. Michael Egger, Petitioner v. William Casey, Director,
Central Intelligence Agency, et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until March
31, 1986, within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a)
and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this
Court. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens dissent-
ing: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S.

MONDAY, MARCH 10, 1986
451
928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without
reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.

Thurston Kibbe, Administratrix of Estate of Clinton Thurston. Petition.
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the First
Circuit granted. Justice Brennan took no part in the consideration or
decision of this petition.

No. 85-337. Ralph Kemp, Warden, Petitioner v. Jack Howard Potts.
The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by The
Chief Justice, with whom Justice Rehnquist joins. Justice Brennan took
no part in the consideration or decision of this motion and this petition.
No. 85-684. Judith Kramer, Petitioner v. Public Employment Rela-
tions Commission. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court
of New Jersey denied. Justice Blackmun would grant the petition for a
writ of certiorari, vacate the judgment and remand the case to the
Supreme Court of New Jersey for further consideration in light of
Chicago Teachers Union, Local No. 1, AFT, AFL-CIO v. Hudson, 475
U.S. — (1986). Justice Brennan took no part in the consideration or
decision of this petition.

No. 85-6236. In Re Michael Lee Tucker, Petitioner. The petition for
writ of mandamus is denied. Justice Brennan took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this petition.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 85-748. George A. Keller, Petitioner v. United States;
No. 85-790. William H. Cuddy, Petitioner v. Gerald P. Carmen,
Administrator, General Services Administration;
No. 85-5360. Tony Darwin, Petitioner v. United States;
No. 85-5619. Rex B. Campbell, Petitioner v. Department of Trans-
portation, Federal Aviation Administration; and
No. 85-5885. Michael Lee Tucker, Petitioner v. United States. The
petitions for rehearing are denied. Justice Brennan took no part in the
consideration or decision of these petitions.
No. 85-5352. Henry T. Sanders, Petitioner v. The Junior College
District of Metropolitan Kansas City, Missouri; and
No. 85-5413. Margarite Petrillo, Petitioner v. New Jersey. The
motions for leave to file petitions for rehearing are denied. Justice
Brennan took no part in the consideration or decision of these motions.

458
MONDAY, MARCH 10, 1986
ORDERS
Ordered:
1. That the Federal Rules of Appellate Procedure be, and they are
hereby, amended by including therein new Appellate Rules 3.1, 5.1,
and 15.1 and amendments to Appellate Rules 3(d), 8(b), 10(b) and (c),
11(b), 12(a), 19, 23(b) and (c), 24(a), 25(a) and (b), 26(a) and (c), 28(c)
and (j), 30(a), (b) and (c), 31(a) and (c), 34(a) and (e), 39(c) and (d), 43(a)
and (c), 45(a), (b), and (d), and 46(a) and (b).
2. That the foregoing additions to and changes in the Federal Rules of
Appellate Procedure shall take effect on July 1, 1986 and shall govern all
proceedings in appellate actions thereafter commenced and, insofar as
just and practicable, all proceedings in appellate actions then pending.
3. That the Chief Justice be, and he hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing additions to and changes in the rules of
appellate procedure in accordance with the provisions of Section 3772 of
Title 18 and Section 2072 of Title 28, United States Code.

OPINIONS
No. 84-1485. John Moran, Superintendent, Rhode Island Department
of Corrections, Petitioner v. Brian K. Burbine. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Brennan and
Justice Marshall join.
No. 84–1580. United States, Petitioner v. Joseph Inadi. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with whom
Justice Brennan joins.

464
MONDAY, MARCH 10, 1986
No. 84-978. Exxon Corporation, et al., Appellants v. Robert Hunt,
Administrator of New Jersey Spill Compensation Fund, et al. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of New Jersey. Judgment affirmed in part, re-
versed in part, and case remanded to the Supreme Court for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens. Justice Powell
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MARCH 11, 1986
469
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-691. Charles William Bass, Applicant v. O. L. McCotter, Di-
rector, Texas Department of Corrections. The application for stay of
execution of the sentence of death, scheduled for Wednesday, March
12, 1986 presented to Justice White and by him referred to the Court is
denied. Dissenting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.



(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MARCH 18, 1986
471
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 85-6545. Davidson J. James, Petitioner v. Louie L. Wainwright,
Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections, et al. The application
for stay of execution of sentence of death, scheduled for Wednesday,
March 19, 1986, presented to Justice Powell and by him referred to the
Court, is granted until April 7, 1986, or until the disposition by this
Court of the petition for a writ of certiorari, whichever is earlier, unless
otherwise extended by the Court. The Chief Justice, Justice White,
Justice Rehnquist and Justice O'Connor would deny the application for
stay.
No. 85-6547. Roy A. Harich, Petitioner v. Louie L. Wainwright, Sec-
retary, Florida Department of Corrections, et al. The application for
stay of execution of sentence of death, scheduled for Wednesday, March
19, 1986, presented to Justice Powell and by him referred to the Court
is denied. Concurring opinion by Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall. Dissenting
statement by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Blackmun joins.



(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, MARCH 20, 1986
473
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 85-6557. Arthur Lee Jones, petitioner v. Fred Smith, Commis-
sioner, Alabama Department of Corrections, et al. The application for
stay of execution of sentence of death, scheduled for Friday, March 21,
1986, presented to Justice Powell and by him referred to the Court is
denied. Dissenting statement by Justice Brennan with whom Justice
Marshall joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Jus-
tice Brennan joins. Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens would grant
the application for stay.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 24, 1986
475
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 85-1256. Marian Fleming Comstock, Appellant v. Harris
County, Texas. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Texas, Fourteenth
Supreme Judicial District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
| tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 85-5400. Wayne R. Anderson, Appellant v. District Court of
Jefferson County, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Colorado.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 85-6307. Leo L. Eigenman, Appellant v. California. Appeal from
the Superior Court of California, County of Tulare. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 85-1271. Covenant Community Church, Appellant v. Tommy
Lowe, Knox County Clerk. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Tennes-
see, Eastern Division. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 85-1275. Robert L. York, Appellant v. Office of Disciplinary
Counsel of Supreme Court of Ohio. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Ohio. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 85-1296. Jean Rosenbaum, Appellant v. Kurt Rosenbaum. Ap-
peal from the Appellate Court of Illinois, First District. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 85-1311. Stuart Green and Leslie Green, Appellants v. West
Virginia Department of Human Services. Appeal from the Circuit
Court of West Virginia, Jefferson County. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.

476
MONDAY, MARCH 24, 1986
No. 85-6217. Harold G. Rederth, Appellant v. South Dakota. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of South Dakota. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 85-23. Maryland, Petitioner v. Kenneth James Lodowski. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Maryland. The
petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Court of Appeals of Maryland for further
consideration in light of Moran v. Burbine, 475 U.S. — (1986).
-
No. 85-1074. Florida, Petitioner v. Jerry Haliburton. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida. The motion of re-
spondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The peti-
tion for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the
case is remanded to the Supreme Court of Florida for further consider-
ation in light of Moran v. Burbine, 475 U.S. (1986).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . Bernard Fitzgerald, etc., Petitioner v. City of Philadelphia.
The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari,
out-of-time, is denied.

ald J. Higgs, et al. The application to continue the stay of mandate of
the Supreme Court of Colorado presented to Justice White and by him
referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-123. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jerry F. Chvosta. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-404. In the Matter of Disbarment of Raymond Mirrer. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-541. In the Matter of Disbarment of Calvin Roosevelt
Boulding. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-548. In the Matter of Disbarment of John Harrison Marble. It
is ordered that John Harrison Marble, of Cincinnati, Ohio, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-549. In the Matter of Disbarment of Charles Louis Duke. It is
ordered that Charles Louis Duke, of Houston, Texas, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable

MONDAY, MARCH 24, 1986
477
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 105, Original. State of Kansas, Plaintiff v. State of Colorado.
The motion for leave to file a bill of complaint is granted. Defendant is
allowed sixty days within which to file an answer.
No. 84-6075. Ricky Wayne Tison and Raymond Curtis Tison, Peti-
tioners v. Arizona. The motions for appointment of counsel are granted
and it is ordered that Alan M. Dershowitz, Esquire, of Cambridge,
Massachusetts, is appointed to serve as counsel for the petitioners in
this case.
No. 85-246. United States, Petitioner v. Dwight Dion, Sr. The
motion of the Solicitor General to permit Jeffrey P. Minear, Esquire, to
present oral argument pro hace vice is granted.
No. 85-499. B. H. Papasan, Superintendent of Education, et al.,
Petitioners v. Mississippi, et al. The motion of the Attorney General of
Mississippi to strike brief of respondents Dick Molpus, Secretary of
State of Mississippi, et al., is denied.
No. 85-519. William C. Randall, Roger E. Austin, Tom W. Anderson
and Myrel A. Neumann, Petitioners v. B. J. Loftsgaarden, et al. The
motion of petitioners for divided argument is denied.
No. 85-954. Japan Whaling Association and Japan Fisheries Associa-
tion, Petitioners v. American Cetacean Society, et al.; and
No. 85-955. Malcolm Baldrige, Secretary of Commerce, et al., Peti-
tioners v. American Cetacean Society, et al. The motion of the Solicitor
General for divided argument is granted.
No. 85-1455. Jose Carlos Prado, Petitioner v. United States. The
application for stay addressed to Justice Stevens and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. 85-1468. Eugene P. Woods, Petitioner v. Superior Court of Cali-
fornia, County of Alameda (Helen J. Jones, Real Party in Interest).
The application for stay addressed to Justice Brennan and referred to
the Court is denied.

Cross for the petitioner and by Mr. Gary H. Lee for the respondents.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MARCH 25, 1986
499
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 84-773. Michael Bender, et al., Petitioners v. Williamsport Area
School District, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals with instructions to dismiss the appeal for want of
jurisdiction. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Concurring opinion by Justice
Marshall. Dissenting opinion by the Chief Justice with whom Justice
White and Justice Rehnquist join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Powell.
No. 84-1097. S. Simcha Goldman, Petitioner v. Casper W. Weinber-
ger, Secretary of Defense, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Concurring opinion by Justice
Stevens with whom Justice White and Justice Powell join. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Con-
nor with whom Justice Marshall joins.
No. 84-1160. Bertold J. Pembaur, Petitioner v. City of Cincinnati, et
al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Justice Brennan delivered the opinion of the Court except as to
Part II-B. Concurring opinion by Justice White. Opinion by Justice
Stevens concurring in part and concurring in the judgment. Opinion by
Justice O'Connor concurring in part and concurring in the judgment.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Powell with whom the Chief Justice and
Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 85-88. Barbara Ann Paulussen, Appellant v. George Ronald
Herion. Appeal from the Superior Court of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia
Office. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Superior Court of
Pennsylvania for further consideration in light of the intervening
change in state law. Opinion per curiam announced by the Chief
Justice.

tioners v. Zenith Radio Corporation, et al. On writ of certiorari to the

versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Powell. Dissenting opinion by Justice White with whom Justice Bren-
nan, Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens join.

Correctional Institution, Norfolk, Massachusetts, et al., Petitioners v.
Charles Flynn. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the First Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Marshall. Concurring opinion
by the Chief Justice.

MONDAY, MARCH 31, 1986
503
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 85-1261. Floyd Meyers and Rita Meyers, Appellants v. Seneca
County Board of Commissioners. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Ohio. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
A-703. Vi Fedora, Applicant v. National Labor Relations Board. The
application for stay pending the appeal addressed to Justice Powell and
referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-536. In the Matter of Disbarment of Lee Gilson Lovett. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-538. In the Matter of Disbarment of William V. Vetter. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-539. In the Matter of Disbarment of Donald H. Mueller. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-540. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard G. Chosid. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-550. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert Scott Michaels. It
is ordered that Robert Scott Michaels, of Beverly Hills, California, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-551. In the Matter of Disbarment of Zane Gray Nichols. It is
ordered that Zane Gray Nichols, of Annapolis, Maryland, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 103, Original. State of South Dakota, Plaintiff v. States of
Nebraska, Iowa and Missouri. The motion of North Dakota for leave to

504
MONDAY, MARCH 31, 1986
intervene as plaintiff is granted. The motion for leave to file a bill of
complaint is denied without prejudice.
No. 84–1379. Eugene F. Diamond and Jasper F. Williams, Appel-
lants v. Allan G. Charles, et al. The motion of appellants for leave to file
a supplemental brief after argument is granted.
No. 84–1777. International Union, United Automobile, Aerospace,
etc., et al., Petitioners v. William E. Brock, Secretary, United States
Department of Labor. The motion of Chamber of Commerce of the
United States, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae, out-of-
time, is granted.
No. 85-473. Cargill, Inc. and Excel Corporation, Petitioners v. Mon-
fort of Colorado, Inc. The motion of the parties to permit filing one vol-
ume of joint appendix under seal is granted. Justice Blackmun took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 85-521. Otis R. Bowen, Secretary of Health and Human Serv-
ices, et al., Appellants v. Public Agencies Opposed to Social Security
Entrapment, et al. The motion of appellees Public Agencies Opposed to
Social Security Entrapment, et al. for leave to file out-of-time motion
for divided argument is denied.
No. 85-599. United States, Petitioner v. American Bar Endowment,
et al. The motion of California Farm Bureau Federation for leave to file
a brief as amicus curiae is granted. Justice Powell and Justice O'Con-
nor took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 85-1377. Charles A. Bowsher, Comptroller General of the
United States, Appellant v. Mike Synar, Member of Congress, et al.;
No. 85-1378. United States Senate, Appellant v. Mike Synar, Mem-
ber of Congress, et al.; and
No. 85-1379. Thomas P. O'Neill, Jr., Speaker of the United States
House of Representatives, et al., Appellants v. Mike Synar, Member of
Congress, et.al. The motion of National Treasury Employees Union for
leave to add an individual party plaintiff is granted.
No. 85-1459. James H. Powell, Appellant v. Ruth Ann Powell. The
application for recall and stay addressed to the Chief Justice and re-
ferred to the Court is denied.
APPEAL JURISDICTION POSTPONED
No. 85-1200. California Coastal Commission, et al., Appellants v.
Granite Rock Company. Appeal from the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Further consideration of the question of
Jurisdiction is postponed to the hearing of the case on the merits.

v. Allied Chemical International Corp. The motion of Inter-American
Freight Conference, Sections A and D, for leave to file a brief as
amicus curiae is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit denied.
No. 85-6264. Ronald Straight, Petitioner v. Louie L. Wainwright,
Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections, et al. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh
Circuit denied. Dissenting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice
Marshall. Justice Blackmun dissents.
No. 85-6324. Johnny Watkins, Jr., Petitioner v. Virginia. The peti-
tion for a writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Virginia denied.
Opinion by Justice Stevens respecting the denial of the petition for
certiorari. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Justice
Brennan joins.
No. 85-6448. Aubrey Dennis Adams, Petitioner v. Louie L. Wain-
wright, Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections, et al. The appli-
cation for stay of execution of the sentence of death presented to Justice
Powell and by him referred to the Court is denied. The stay of execu-
tion heretofore granted is vacated. The petition for a writ of certiorari
to the Supreme Court of Florida denied. Justice Brennan and Justice
Marshall would grant the application for stay, the petition for writ of
certiorari and vacate the death sentence in this case.
No. 85-6470. Aubrey Dennis Adams, Petitioner v. Florida. The ap-
plication for stay of execution of the sentence of death presented to Jus-
tice Powell and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for
a writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida is denied. Justice
Brennan and Justice Marshall would grant the application for stay, the
petition for a certiorari and vacate the death sentence in this case.

MONDAY, MARCH 31, 1986
511
No. 85-6476. Aubrey Dennis Adams, Petitioner v. Louie L. Wain-
wright, Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. The application
for stay of execution of the sentence of death presented to Justice Pow-
ell and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for a writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida is denied. Justice Brennan
and Justice Marshall would grant the application for stay, the petition
for a writ of certiorari, and vacate the death sentence in this case.
COMMON LAW CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 85-6368. In Re Arlene A. Kierstead, Petitioner. The petition for
common law certiorari is denied.
MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 85-6371. In Re Elijah Karriem, Elroy X. Lewis and Connie Wil-
kins, Jr., Petitioners. The petition for writ of mandamus and/or prohi-
bition is denied.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 84-744. United States, Petitioner v. James C. Lane and Dennis
R. Lane;
No. 85-1179. Arnold Sonderegger, Petitioner v. E. F. Hutton &
Company, Inc., et al.;
No. 85-5865. Clifford Howard, Petitioner v. United States;
No. 85-5893. Arthur Nickens, Petitioner v. Mississippi;
No. 85-5931. Thomas Dyson, Appellant v. Texas; and
No. 85-6078. Edward Muza, Petitioner v. United States. The peti-
tions for rehearing are denied.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, April 7, 1986, until Mon-
day, April 21, 1986.

of Revenue. Argued by Mr. Walter D. Hansen for the appellant, by Mr.
Albert G. Lauber, Jr., for the United States as amicus curiae, in sup-
port of the appellant, by special leave of Court, and by Mr. Joseph C.

TUESDAY, APRIL 1, 1986
517
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 84-1531. Michigan, Petitioner v. Robert Bernard Jackson; and
No. 84–1539. Michigan, Petitioner v. Rudy Bladel. On writs of certio-
rari to the Supreme Court of Michigan. Judgments affirmed. Opinion by
Justice Stevens. Opinion by the Chief Justice concurring in the judg-
ment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist with whom Justice Pow-
ell and Justice O'Connor join.
No. 84-1644. Golden State Transit Corporation, Petitioner v. City
of Los Angeles. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Rehnquist.
ORAL ARGUMENTS
No. 85-162. New Mexico, Petitioner v. Ralph Rodney Earnest.
Argued by Mr. Paul Bardacke for the petitioner and by Mr. J. Thomas
Sullivan for the respondent.
No. 85-198. Celotex Corporation, Petitioner, v. Myrtle Nell Catrett,
Administratrix of the Estate of Louis H. Catrett, deceased. Argued by
Mr. Leland S. Van Koten for the petitioner and by Mr. Paul March
Smith for the respondent.

Pierce County. Argued by Mr. Andrew J. Pincus for the petitioner and
by Mr. Joseph F. Quinn for the respondent.
No. 84–1744. Thomas J. Henderson, Scott O. Thornton and Ruth
Freedman, Petitioners v. United States. Argued by Ms. Denise Anton
for the petitioners and by Mr. Roger Clegg for the respondent.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 7, 1986
521
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 85-1418. Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company, Appellant v.
Superior Court of California, County of San Bernardino (Mary Denise
Mitchell, et al., Real Parties in Interest). Appeal from the Court of
Appeal of California, Fourth Appellate District. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 85-1452. John Lauve, Appellant v. Secretary of State of Michi-
gan; and John Lauve, Appellant v. Attorney General of Michigan et al.;
and John Lauve v. Secretary of State of Michigan. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Michigan. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 85-6451. Delores Ann Wesley, Appellant v. Texas. Appeal from
the Sixty-sixth Judicial District Court of Texas, Hill County. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-6677. Emmett Murray Holloway, Petitioner v. Texas. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas.
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the
petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas for fur-
ther consideration in light of Michigan v. Jackson, 475 U. S. -
(1986) and Moran v. Burbine, 475 U. S. (1986).
No. 85-249. City of Little Rock, Petitioner v. Debbie Williams. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States

522
MONDAY, APRIL 7, 1986
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further consideration in
light of Pembur v. City of Cincinnati, 475 U. S.
(1986).
No. 85-487. Ford Motor Company, et al., Petitioners v. Tunis Broth-
ers Company, Inc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further
consideration in light of Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., Ltd. v.
Zenith Radio Corporation, 475 U. S. (1986).
No. 85-6318. John C. MacLean, Petitioner v. City of Bellingham,
Washington. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of
Washington, Division 1. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the Court of Appeals
of Washington, Division 1, for further consideration in light of Pembaur
v. City of Cincinnati, 475 U. S. (1986).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. —. Robert D. Cook, Petitioner v. Chiu-An Wang, et al. The
motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-
time is denied.
No. A-694. Bankers' Life and Casualty Company, Applicant v. Lloyd
M. Crenshaw. The application for stay pending appeal addressed to the
Chief Justice and referred to the Court is denied. Justice Blackmun and
Justice Stevens would grant this application.
No. A-756. Curtis Lee Johnson, Applicant v. Texas. The application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice White
and by him referred to the Court is granted pending the filing of a peti-
tion for writ of certiorari on or before May 7, 1986. If the petition is
filed on or before May 7, 1986, this order is to continue in effect pending
this Court's final disposition of the petition for writ of certiorari.
No. D-533. In the Matter of Disbarment of Levi W. Evans, III. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-543. In the Matter of Disbarment of Riner Ernest Deglow.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-544. In the Matter of Disbarment of Kenneth L. Tilley. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-552. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard J. Plaza. It is
ordered that Richard J. Plaza, of Jersey City, New Jersey, be sus-

MONDAY, APRIL 7, 1986
523
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 84-1379. Eugene F. Diamond and Jasper F. Williams, Appel-
lants v. Allan G. Charles, et al. The motion of appellees for leave to file
a supplemental brief after argument is granted.
No. 85-250. Richard E. Lyng, Secretary of Agriculture, Appellant v.
Natividad Castillo, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General to permit
Jeffrey P. Minear, Esquire, to present oral argument pro hac vice is
granted.
No. 85-437. Richard Arcara, District Attorney of Erie County, Peti-
tioner v. Cloud Books, Inc., etc., et al. The motion of City of Santa Ana
for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae, for divided
argument and for additional time for oral argument is denied.
No. 85-473. Cargill, Inc. and Excel Corporation, Petitioners v. Mon-
fort of Colorado, Inc. The motion of The Business Roundtable for leave
to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. Justice Blackmun took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 85-920. Alaska Airlines, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. William E.
Brock, Secretary of Labor, et al. The motion of petitioners to dispense
with printing the joint appendix is granted.
No. 85-1377. Charles A. Bowsher, Comptroller General of the
United States, Appellant v. Mike Synar, Member of Congress, et al.;
No. 85-1378. United States Senate, Appellant v. Mike Synar, Mem-
ber of Congress, et al.; and
No. 85-1379. Thomas P. O'Neill, Jr., Speaker of the United States
House of Representatives, et al., Appellants v. Mike Synar, Member of
Congress, et al. The motion of the parties for divided argument is
granted.
No. 85-6545. Davidson J. James, Petitioner v. Louie L. Wainwright,
Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections, et al. The stay order
granted March 18, 1986, is continued pending final disposition of the
petition for writ of certiorari.

OPINIONS
No. 84-1279. Delaware, Petitioner v. Robert E. Van Arsdall. On
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Delaware. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the Supreme Court for further proceedings not
inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Rehn-
quist. Opinion by Justice White concurring in the judgment. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 84-1725. United States, Petitioner v. City of Fulton, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Marshall.
No. 84-1913. AT&T Technologies, Inc., Petitioner v. Communica-
tions Workers of America, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Con-
curring opinion by Justice Brennan with whom the Chief Justice and
Justice Marshall join.

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, APRIL 11, 1986
539
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 85-6679. Daniel M. Thomas, Petitioner v. Louie L. Wainwright,
Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. The application for stay
of execution of the sentence of death presented to Justice Powell and by
him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for writ of certiorari to
the Supreme Court of Florida is denied. Dissenting statement by Jus-
tice Brennan and Justice Marshall.



(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, APRIL 15, 1986
541
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 85-6714. Daniel M. Thomas, Petitioner v. Louie L. Wainwright,
Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. The application for a
certificate of probable cause presented to Justice Powell and by him
referred to the Court is denied. The application for stay of execution of
sentence of death presented to Justice Powell and by him referred to
the Court is denied. The petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit is denied. Dissenting
statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 21, 1986
543
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 85-531. City of Los Angeles, et al., Petitioners v. Ronald Heller.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Marshall joins. Justice
Brennan took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 85-1150. Dennison Manufacturing Company, Petitioner v. Pan-
duit Corp. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 85–1093. Shirley M. Ryniawec, Appellant v. Callie Tsapis,
Judge, Circuit Court of Brooke County, West Virginia, et al. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 85-6403. Thomas Dyson, Appellant v. Texas A & M University.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 85-1343. Mark A. Humphrey and Fred J. Haas, dba Humphrey
& Haas, Appellants v. Committee on Professional Ethics and Conduct
of the Iowa State Bar Association. Appeal from the Supreme Court of

544
MONDAY, APRIL 21, 1986
Iowa. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal ques-
tion. Justice White, Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens would note
probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral argument.
No. 85-1392. Richard Pullum, Appellant v. Cincinnati, Inc., etc.,
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 85-1407. Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc.,
et al., Appellants v. Public Service Commission of New York. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 85-6499. John J. Staradumsky, Appellant v. Rhode Island.
Appeal from the District Court of Rhode Island, Sixth Division. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 85-299. Royal Center, Inc., Petitioner v. Local Joint Executive
Board of Las Vegas, Culinary Workers Union, Local 226, et al. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of AT&T
Technologies, Inc. v. Communications Workers of America, 475 U.S.
(1986).
No. 85-875. Rhode Island, Petitioner v. Luigi Manocchio. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Rhode Island. The peti-
tion for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the
case is remanded to the Supreme Court of Rhode Island for further con-
sideration in light of Delaware v. Van Arsdall, 475 U.S. (1986).
No. 85-1026. Texas, Petitioner v. Kenneth Earl Jackson. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The
motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated
and the case is remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas for
further consideration in light of Texas v. McCullough, 475 U.S.
(1986).
No. 85-1434. James Tierney, et al., Petitioners v. City of Toledo,
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further con-

MONDAY, APRIL 21, 1986
545
sideration in light of Chicago Teachers Union, Local No. 1, AFT,
AFL-CIO v. Hudson, 475 U. S. (1986).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . Daniel P. Cribb, et al., Petitioners v. L. B. Pelham, etc., et
al. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari,
out-of-time, is denied.
-
No. —. Robert Cox, Petitioner v. LeMaire, Fauntz & Katznelson.
The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari,
out-of-time, is denied.
No. D-554. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jack R. Wood. It is
ordered that Jack R. Wood, of Shelbyville, Indiana, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-555. In the Matter of Disbarment of William John Kerpan. It
is ordered that William John Kerpan, of Marysville, Pennsylvania, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 74, Original. State of Georgia, Plaintiff v. State of South Caro-
lina. The First Report of the Special Master is received and ordered
filed.
No. 85-236. Harry W. Eichenlaub, Petitioner v. David Alan Yurky,
et al. The motion of respondents Zimmerman and Wicker for divided
argument is granted. The request for additional time for oral argument
is denied.
No. 85-473. Cargill, Inc. and Excel Corporation, Petitioners v. Mon-
fort of Colorado, Inc. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to
participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument
is granted. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this motion.
No. 85-488. Ohio Civil Rights Commission, et al, Appellants v. Day-
ton Christian Schools, Inc., et al. The motion of appellees for leave to
file a supplemental brief after argument is granted.
No. 85-660. Colorado, Petitioner v. Francis Barry Connelly. The
motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral argument
as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted.

setts Citizens for Life, Inc. The motion of Chamber of Commerce of the

MONDAY, APRIL 21, 1986
United States for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The

Rose and Tennessee. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in

No. 85-1377. Charles A. Bowsher, Comptroller General of the
United States, Appellant v. Mike Synar, Member of Congress, et al.;
No. 85-1378. United States Senate, Appellant v. Mike Synar, Mem-
ber of Congress, et al.; and
No. 85-1379. Thomas P. O'Neill, Jr., Speaker of the United States
House of Representatives, et al., Appellants v. Mike Synar, Member of
Congress, et al. The motion of Edward Blankstein for leave to file a
brief as amicus curiae, out-of-time, is granted. The motion of American
Jewish Congress for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae, out-of-time,
is granted.
No. 85-6214. Wayne Lindahl, Petitioner v. Office of Personnel Man-
agement. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma paupe-
ris is denied. Petitioner is allowed until May 12, 1986, within which to
pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in
compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens, dissenting:
For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928
(1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without
reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 85-6418. George R. Issa, Petitioner v. Merit Systems Protection
Board. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
二

MONDAY, APRIL 21, 1986
547
is denied. Petitioner is allowed until May 12, 1986, within which to pay
the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in
compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan,
Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons ex-
pressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would
deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of
the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.

the merits.

No. 85-1277. School Board of Nassau County, Florida and Craig
Marsh, Individually and as Superintendent of Schools of Nassau
County, Florida, Petitioners v. Gene H. Arline. The motion of respond-
ent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh
Circuit granted limited to Question 1 presented by the petition. In addi-
tion, the parties are requested to brief and argue the following ques-
tion: "Whether one who is afflicted with the contagious, infectious dis-
ease of tuberculosis is precluded from being ‘otherwise qualified' for the
job of elementary-school teacher, within the meaning of Section 504 of

548
MONDAY, APRIL 21, 1986
the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, 29 U.S.C. Sect. 794?" Dissenting opinion
by Justice Stevens.
No. 85-6461. Earline Martin, Petitioner v. Ohio. The motion of Ohio
Public Defender Commission for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma paupe-
ris is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court
of Ohio is granted limited to Question IV presented by the petition.

OPINIONS
No. 84–1491. Philadelphia Newspapers, Inc., et al., Appellants v.
Maurice S. Hepps, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Pennsylva-
nia, Eastern District. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Supreme Court for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opin-
ion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Concurring opinion by
Justice Brennan with whom Justice Blackmun joins. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Stevens with whom the Chief Justice, Justice White and
Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 84-1288. John V. Evans, et al., Petitioners v. Jeff D., et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with
whom Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun join.
No. 85-195. Icicle Seafoods, Inc., Petitioner v. Larry Worthington,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Stevens.
No. 84-1717. United States, Petitioner v. Michael Robert Quinn. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth

570
MONDAY, APRIL 21, 1986
Circuit. The writ of certiorari is dismissed as improvidently granted.
Opinion per curiam announced by the Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion
by the Chief Justice with whom Justice Blackmun joins.

Video, et al. On writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of New York.

ther proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with
whom Justice Brennan and Justice Stevens join.

Treasury of the United States and United States. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Stevens.

cians. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Federal Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion.
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Marshall. Concurring opinion by the
Chief Justice with whom Justice Powell joins.

Lavoie and Roger J. Lavoie, Sr. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Alabama. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Supreme Court
for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by the Chief Justice. Concurring opinion by Justice Brennan.
Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring in the judgment with whom
Justice Marshall joins. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration.
or decision of this case.

MONDAY, APRIL 28, 1986
577
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 84-1672. Maurice S. Hepps, et al., Appellants v. Philadelphia
Newspapers, Inc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Pennsylva-
nia, Eastern District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 85-6501. Beatrice L. Robinson, Appellant v. United States.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Co-
lumbia Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treat-
ing the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 85-6004. Bret Clark, Appellant v. Florida. Appeal from the Dis-
trict Court of Appeal of Florida, Fifth District. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Opinion by
The Chief Justice respecting the dismissal.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 85-1295. J. C. Tyus, Petitioner v. Francisco Eugenio Martinez.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit to consider the question of
mootness.
No. 85-1446. United Retail Workers Union, Local 881, etc., Peti-
tioner v. National Labor Relations Board and May Department Stores
Company. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further con-

578
MONDAY, APRIL 28, 1986
sideration in light of National Labor Relations Board v. Financial
Institution Employees of America, Local 1182, 475 U. S. (1986).
No. 85-6213. Kenneth E. Murphy, Petitioner v. Manfred Holland,
Warden. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Michigan v. Jackson, 475 U. S. (1986).

ORDER
585
It is ordered that the call of the calendar, except for special assign-
ments, be suspended for the Term upon the conclusion of the argu-
ments in the cases listed for hearing this week.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, May 5, 1986, until Mon-
day, May 19, 1986.

TUESDAY, APRIL 29, 1986
591
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 85-5189. Lamont Julius McLaughlin, Petitioner v. United
States. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 84-6859. Ronald DeRay Skipper, Petitioner v. South Carolina.
On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of South Carolina. Judg-
ment reversed insofar as it affirms the death sentence, and case re-
manded to the Supreme Court for further proceedings not inconsistent
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Opinion by
Justice Powell concurring in the judgment with whom the Chief Justice
and Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 84-1728. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, Peti-
tioner v. Federal Labor Relations Authority, et al. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Cir-
cuit. Writ of certiorari is dismissed as improvidently granted. Opinion
per curiam announced by the Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice White. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.

OPINIONS
No. 84-6263. James Kirkland Batson, Petitioner v. Kentucky. On
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Kentucky. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Supreme Court for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Powell. Concurring opinion by Justice White. Concurring opinion by
Justice Marshall. Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens with whom
Justice Brennan joins. Concurring opinion by Justice O'Connor. Dis-
senting opinion by the Chief Justice with whom Justice Rehnquist joins.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist with whom the Chief Justice
joins.
No. 84-1379. Eugene F. Diamond and Jasper F. Williams, Appel-
lants v. Allan G. Charles, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Opinion by Justice O'Connor con-
curring in part and concurring in the judgment with whom the Chief
Justice and Justice Rehnquist join. Justice White concurs in the
judgment.
No. 84–6646. Willie Lloyd Turner, Petitioner v. Edward W. Murray,
Director, Virginia Department of Corrections. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Justice White
announced the judgment of the Court and delivered the opinion of the
Court with respect to Parts I and III, and an opinion with respect to

594
WEDNESDAY, APRIL 30, 1986
Parts II and IV, in which Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, and
Justice O'Connor join. The Chief Justice concurs in the judgment.
Opinion by Justice Brennan concurring in part and dissenting in part.
Opinion by Justice Marshall concurring in the judgment in part and dis-
senting in part with whom Justice Brennan joins. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Powell with whom Justice Rehnquist joins.
ORAL ARGUMENTS

Verlin R. Meinz for the petitioner and by Mr. Mark L. Rotert for the
respondent.

Ann Ricker Campbell, Individually, and as Administratrix of the Es-
tate of Prince Rupert Ricker, Deceased. Argued by Mr. R. Stephen
McNally for the appellant and by Mr. Paul McCollum for the appellee.
No. 85-664. Frank Young, Commissioner of Food and Drug Adminis-
tration, Petitioner v. Community Nutrition Institute, et al. Argued by
Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr., for the petitioner and by Mr. William B.
Schultz for the respondents.

tion, Petitioners v. American Cetacean Society, et al.; and
No. 85-955. Malcolm Baldrige, Secretary of Commerce, et al., Peti-

the petitioners in No. 85-954, and by Mr. William D. Rogers for the
respondents in both cases.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 5, 1986
595
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Justice Brennan, Justice White, Justice Marshall, Justice
Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, and Jus-
tice O'Connor.
Justice Brennan said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by me, filed with the
Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 85-1425. Republican Party of Hawaii, et al., Appellants v. Patsy
Mink, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Hawaii. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 85-6104. George Cordova, Appellant v. Texas. Appeal from the
Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Dissenting statement
by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-1783. Richard Gerald Jordan, Petitioner v. Mississippi. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Mississippi. The
petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Supreme Court of Mississippi for further
consideration in light of Skipper v. South Carolina, 476 U. S.
(1986).
No. 84-1942. Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company, Petitioner v.
Henry Gerrard Clay. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of Alabama. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the Supreme Court of
Alabama for further consideration in light of Aetna Life Insurance Co.
v. Lavoie, 475 U. S. (1986).
-
No. 85-5087. Edward Lee Elmore, Petitioner v. South Carolina. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of South Carolina.
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the
petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Supreme Court of South Carolina for fur-
ther consideration in light of Skipper v. South Carolina, 476 U. S.
(1986).
-

596
MONDAY, MAY 5, 1986
No. 85-5339. Donald Allen Jones, Petitioner v. South Carolina. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of South Carolina.
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the
petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Supreme Court of South Carolina for fur-
ther consideration in light of Skipper v. South Carolina, 476 U. S.
(1986).
No. 85-5411. Jerry W. Plemmons, Petitioner v. South Carolina. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of South Carolina.
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the
petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Supreme Court of South Carolina for fur-
ther consideration in light of Skipper v. South Carolina, 476 U. S. ·
(1986).
-
No. 85-6063. Manuel Valle, Petitioner v. Florida. On petition for writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida. The motion of petitioner
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of cer-
tiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the Supreme Court of Florida for further consideration in light of
Skipper v. South Carolina, 476 U. S. (1986).

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . Eugene Leslie, Petitioner v. United States. The motion to
direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari which does not
comply with the Rules of the Court is denied.
No. A-760. James E. Smith, Applicant v. United States. The applica-
tion for bail pending appeal addressed to Justice Stevens and referred
to the Court is denied.
No. A-804. Seaboard System Railroad, Inc., Applicant v. Thurman
Page, Jr. The application for stay pending appeal presented to Justice
Powell and by him referred to the Court is denied. Justice Blackmun
would grant the application.
No. D-553. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ray Velasquez. It is
ordered that Ray Velasquez, of Marlow Heights, Maryland, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-556. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael Samuel Sodo-
wick. It is ordered that Michael Samuel Sodowick, of West Caldwell,
New Jersey, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and

MONDAY, MAY 5, 1986
597
that a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show
cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this
Court.
No. 81, Original. Commonwealth of Kentucky, Plaintiff v. State of
Indiana, et al. The Accounting of the Special Master is received and
ordered filed. The Special Master appointed by the Court is discharged
with the thanks of the Court.
No. 84-1947. Vincent T. Cerbone, Justice of the Village Court, Vil-
lage of Mt. Kisco, New York, et al., Petitioners v. Lynn H. Conway.
The motion of petitioners for divided argument is denied.
No. 85-488. Ohio Civil Rights Commission, et al, Appellants v. Day-
ton Christian Schools, Inc., et al. The motion of appellants for leave to
file a supplemental brief after argument is granted.
No. 85-1524. Hubbard Broadcasting, Inc., Petitioner v. Southern
Satellite Systems, Inc., and Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. The
Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the
views of the United States.
No. 85-6562. Glenn A. Baxter, Petitioner v. Federal Communica-
tions Commission. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until May 27, 1986,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to
submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For
the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928
(1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without
reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 85-1513. Edwin W. Edwards, etc., et al. Appellants v. Don
Aguillard, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted.

Green, Kentucky, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit denied.
No. 85-6618. JoEtta L. Anesi, etc., Petitioner v. United States
Department of Agriculture. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit denied.
No. 85-6652. Frank Gennuso, Petitioner v. Jerome Eppolito, et al.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit denied.
No. 85-6656. Sam T. Watkins, Petitioner v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Military Appeals
denied.
No. 85-426. Save the Dunes Council, Inc., Petitioner v. United
States, et al. The motion of Sierra Club for leave to file a brief as
amicus curiae is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit denied.
No. 85-953. Ray E. Cagle, Petitioner v. Mary E. C. Carlson, etc.,
et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Arizona,
Division One, denied. Justice White and Justice Powell would grant
certiorari.
No. 85-1362. Paul A. Stern, et al., Petitioners v. Tarrant County
Hospital District, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Justice O'Connor
took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 85-1518. Volkswagen of America et al., Petitioners v. Phyllis A.
Rossell, guardian ad litem of Julie Ann Kennon, a minor. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arizona denied. Justice
O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 85-1490. Susan Basch, et al., Petitioners v. Westinghouse Cor-
poration. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied. Justice Blackmun took no part
in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 85-1801. Patricia Larson, et al., Petitioners v. Fargo Women's
Health Organization, Inc., et al. The motion of appellants to treat the
jurisdictional statement as a petition for writ of certiorari is granted.

Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of North Dakota
denied.

for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Louisiana denied. Justice

No. 85-6276. Theodore Robert Bundy, Petitioner v. Florida. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida denied. Dissent-

for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Mississippi denied. Dis-

writ of habeas corpus is denied.

OPINIONS
No. 84-1865. A. L. Lockhart, Director, Arkansas Department of
Correction, Petitioner v. Ardia V. McCree. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Rehnquist. Justice Blackmun concurs in the result. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Marshall with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Stevens
join.
No. 85-227. Despina Smalis and Ernest Smalis, Petitioners v. Penn-
sylvania. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Penn-
sylvania for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Justice White.
No. 85-5023. Patrick Gene Poland, Petitioner v. Arizona; and
No. 85-5024. Michael Kent Poland, Petitioner v. Arizona. On writs of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arizona. Judgment affirmed. Opin-
ion by Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with whom
Justice Brennan and Justice Blackmun join.

Adjourned until Monday, May 19, 1986 at 10 o'clock.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 85-1517. Colorado, Petitioner v. John Leroy Spring. The motion
of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The
petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Colorado is
granted limited to Question 1 presented by the petition. The application
for stay presented to Justice White and by him referred to the Court is
granted pending the issuance of the mandate of this Court.

WEDNESDAY MAY 14, 1986
619
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-872. Jay Kelly Pinkerton, Applicant v. O. L. McCotter, Di-
rector, Texas Department of Corrections. The application for stay of
execution of the sentence of death presented to Justice White and by
him referred to the Court is denied. Dissenting statement by Justice
Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Justice
Brennan joins.
