MONDAY, MAY 19, 1986
621
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice White, Justice Marshall,
Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist, and Justice
O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS
SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 85-1257. Terry Rogers and Brenda Rogers, Appellants v. Chey-
enne Airport Board and City of Cheyenne. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Wyoming. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 85-1537. Betty O. Muka, Appellant v. Frank A. Carter, Jr.,
Chief Disciplinary Counsel. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Rhode
Island. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 85-1584. Peter S. Niedzwiecki, Appellant v. Circuit Protective
Devices, etc. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treat-
ing the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 85-1606. Whalers' Village Glub, Appellant v. California Coastal
Commission. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Second
Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 85-1612. Daniel R. DeNardo, Appellant v. Patrick Murphy,
et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 85-6573. Jim R. Hunter, Appellant v. Ralph Ellinwood. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of New Mexico. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 85-6674. In Re Thomas Dyson, Appellant. Appeal from the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The appeal is dis-

622
MONDAY, MAY 19, 1986
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 85-6688. Gabriel A. Bury, Appellant v. City of Lakeland, Flor-
ida, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Elev-
enth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari is denied.
No. 85-1596. Stein Distributing Company, Inc., Appellant v. Depart-
ment of the Treasury, Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco & Firearms. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied. Justice White and Justice Rehnquist would postpone ju-
risdiction to the hearing of the case on the merits.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84–2026. A. L. Lockhart, Director, Arkansas Department of
Correction, Petitioner, v. Eugene Issac Pitts. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.
The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eighth Circuit for further consideration in light of Lockhart v.
McCree, 476 U.S. (1986).
No. 84–2027. A. L. Lockhart, Director, Arkansas Department of
Correction, Petitioner v. Paul Ruiz and Earl Van Denton. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit. The motion of respondents for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Lockhart v. McCree, 476 U.S. (1986).
-
No. 84-2028. Willis Sargent, Warden, Petitioner v. Billy Junior
Woodard. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Lockhart v. McCree, 476 U.S. - (1986).
No. 85-5768. Kenneth Griffin, Petitioner v. Louie L. Wainwright,
Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. On petition for writ of

MONDAY, MAY 19, 1986
623
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Cir-
cuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in light of Cabana v.
Bullock, 474 U.S. (1986).

OPINIONS
No. 84–1340. Wendy Wygant, et al., Petitioners v. Jackson Board of
Education, etc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Justice Powell announced the judgment of the
Court and delivered an opinion in which The Chief Justice and Justice
Rehnquist joined, and which Justice O'Connor joined in parts I, II,
III-A, III-B, and V. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concurring in part
and concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice White concurring in
the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Jus-
tice Brennan and Justice Blackmun join. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Stevens.
No. 84-1744. Thomas J. Henderson, Scott O. Thornton and Ruth
Freedman, Petitioners v. United States. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Justice
White with whom Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, and Justice Black-
mun join.
No. 84–1905. Otis R. Bowen, Secretary of Health and Human Serv-
ices, Appellant v. Buenta M. Owens, et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Central District of California. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the District Court for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Powell. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Justice
Brennan joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun.

MONDAY, MAY 19, 1986
643
No. 85-385. William E. Brock, Secretary of Labor, Petitioner v.
Pierce County. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Marshall.
No. 84-1259. Dow Chemical Company, Petitioner v. United States,
etc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Opin-
ion by Justice Powell concurring in Part III and dissenting with whom
Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun join.
No. 84-1513. California, Petitioner v. Dante Carlo Ciraolo. On writ of
certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate District.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeal of Cali-
fornia for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Powell with whom Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, and Justice
Blackmun join.

Adjourned until Tuesday, May 27, 1986.
No. 85-6930. Ronald J. Straight, Petitioner v. Louie L. Wainwright,
Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections, et al. The application
for stay of execution of the sentence of death presented to Justice
Powell and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida is denied. Justice Black-
mun would deny the state habeas petition without prejudice to the
presentation of claims on federal habeas. Dissenting statement by
Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MAY 20, 1986
651
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-891. Louie L. Wainwright, Secretary, Florida Department of
Corrections, Applicant v. William Zeigler. The application of the Attor-
ney General of Florida for an order to dissolve a stay of execution of
sentence of death entered by the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eleventh Circuit presented to Justice Powell and by him referred to
the Court is denied.
No. 85-6947. Ronald J. Straight, Petitioner v. Louie L. Wainwright,
Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections, et al. The order hereto-
fore entered staying the execution of the sentence of death until 5 p.m.,
May 20, 1986, is vacated. The application for stay of execution of the
sentence of death presented to Justice Powell and by him referred to
the Court is denied. Concurring opinion by Justice Powell with whom
the Chief Justice, Justice Rehnquist, and Justice O'Connor join. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins,
and with whom Justice Blackmun joins in all but the first paragraph.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Justice Brennan
joins. Justice Stevens would grant the application for stay of execution.



(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MAY 27, 1986
653
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 85-31. Buenta M. Owens and Kenneth R. Owens, et al., Appel-
lants v. Otis R. Bowen, Secretary of Health and Human Services.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Central District of
California. The appeal is dismissed.
No. 85-1493. Metropolitan Edison Company, et al., Appellants v.
Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission, et al. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Middle District. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 85-1637. Budget Rent-A-Car of Cincinnati, Inc., Appellant v.
Kentucky Revenue Cabinet. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Ken-
tucky. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 85-1610. Northern Indiana Public Service Company, Appellant
v. Citizens Action Coalition of Indiana, Inc., et al. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Indiana. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 85-6635. Gene Wilkerson, Appellant v. Township of East Bruns-
wick, New Jersey. Appeal from the Superior Court of New Jersey,
Appellate Division. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-1859. Stuart Marsh, Petitioner v. Board of Education of the
City of Flint, etc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further

654
TUESDAY, MAY 27, 1986
consideration in light of Wygant v. Jackson Board of Education, 476
U.S.
-
(1986).
No. 85-236. Harry W. Eichenlaub, Petitioner v. David Alan Yurky,
et al. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit to consider whether the
case is moot.
No. 85-912. William E. Brock, Secretary of Labor, Petitioner v.
Southeastern Arizona Governments Organization. On petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir-
cuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of Brock v.
Pierce County, 476 U.S. — (1986).
No. 85-1105. James D. Carter and Christopher Moscatiello, Petition-
ers v. United States;
No. 85-1118. Michael F. Murray, Petitioner v. United States; and
No. 85-1120. John M. Rooney, Petitioner v. United States. On peti-
tions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the First Circuit. The petitions for writs of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the cases are remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the First Circuit for further consideration in light
of Henderson v. United States, 476 U.S. (1986). Justice Stevens
would deny the petitions for writs of certiorari.
No. 85-5040. Haywood Isaac, Petitioner v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further consideration in light of
Henderson v. United States, 476 U.S. (1986). Justice Stevens
would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari.
--
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. Robert Ira Peede, Petitioner v. Florida. The motion to
direct the Clerk to file the petition for a writ of certiorari without the
affidavit in support of the motion for leave to proceed in forma paupe-
ris is granted.
No. D-509. In the Matter of Disbarment of Harry Toussaint Alexan-
der. Disbarment order entered.

TUESDAY, MAY 27, 1986
655
No. D-557. In the Matter of Disbarment of Bruce H. Keiden. It is
ordered that Bruce H. Keiden, of Southfield, Michigan, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 85-88. Barbara Ann Paulussen, Appellant, v. George Ronald
Herion. The motion of appellee to retax costs is denied. Justice Black-
mun would grant this motion.
No. 85-495. Ansonia Board of Education, et al., Petitioners v. Ron-
ald Philbrook, et al. The motion of The Rutherford Institute of Ala-
bama, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.
No. 85-608. Illinois, Petitioner v. Albert Krull, George Lucas and
Salvatore Mucerino. The motion of Americans for Effective Law En-
forcement, Inc., et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.
No. 85-1033. John J. Kelly, Connecticut Chief State's Attorney,
et al., Petitioners v. Carolyn Robinson. The motion of National Gover-
nors' Association, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is
granted.
No. 85-1529. Grumman Aerospace Corporation, Petitioner v. Edwin
Lees Shaw. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case
expressing the views of the United States.
No. 85-1623. Islamic Republic of Iran, et al., Petitioners v. The
Boeing Company, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in
this case expressing the views of the United States.

The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit denied.

writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh

662
TUESDAY, MAY 27, 1986
Circuit denied. Justice White took part in the consideration or decision
of this petition.

writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Louisiana denied. Dissenting
statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.

Warden. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Dissenting statement by Justice
Brennan and Justice Marshall.

writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Louisiana denied. Dissenting
statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.

writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Kentucky denied. Dissenting
statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.

of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Idaho denied. Dissenting state-

Warden. The petition for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit is denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Marshall with whom Justice Brennan joins.

tioner v. United States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United

TUESDAY, MAY 27, 1986
663
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion

No. 85-1321. Rudy J. Ramirez, Petitioner v. California. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of California denied. Dissenting

enth Circuit is dismissed as moot.

No. 85-6823. In Re Bal K. Thaper, Petitioner. The petition for writ
of mandamus is denied.

No. 85-6432. James T. Jackson, Petitioner v. Lanson Newsome,
Warden. The petitions for rehearing are denied.
No. 85-531. City of Los Angeles, et al., Petitioners v. Ronald Heller.
The petition for rehearing is denied. Justice Brennan took no part in the
consideration or decision of this petition.

The Court will take a recess from Tuesday, May 27, 1986, until
Monday, June 2, 1986.

OPINIONS
No. 84-1972. Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Petitioner v.
Philadelphia Gear Corporation. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Justice Blackmun
and Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 85-21. Square D Company and Big D Building Supply Corp., Pe-
titioners v. Niagara Frontier Tariff Bureau, Inc., et al. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Marshall.
No. 85-217. International Longshoremen's Association, AFL-CIO,
Appellant v. Larry Davis. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Alabama.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice White. Opinion by Justice.
Rehnquist concurring in part and concurring in the judgment with
whom Justice Powell, Justice Stevens and Justice O'Connor join. Opin-
ion by Justice Blackmun concurring in part and dissenting in part.
No. 84-871. Louisiana Public Service Commission, Appellant v. Fed-
eral Communications Commission, et al.;
No. 84-889. California and Public Utilities Commission of California,
et al., Petitioners v. Federal Communications Commission and United
States;
No. 84-1054. Public Utilities Commission of Ohio, et al., Petitioners
v. Federal Communications Commission, et al.; and
No. 84–1069. Florida Public Service Commission, Petitioner v. Fed-
eral Communications Commission, et al. Appeal from and on writs of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.
In No. 84-871, the appeal was dismissed. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari was
granted. Judgment reversed and cases remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Brennan. The Chief Justice and Justice
Blackmun dissent. Justice Powell and Justice O'Connor took no part in
the consideration or decision of these cases.
No. 84–1362. Public Service Commission of Maryland, Petitioner v.
Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company of Maryland. On writ of

670
TUESDAY, MAY 27, 1986
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion in Louisiana Public
Service Commission v. Federal Communications Commission, et al.,
ante, at.476 U.S. — (1986).

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 2, 1986
673
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Justice White, Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice
Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
Justice White said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by me, filed with the
Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 85-1344. Robert Julian Taylor, Appellant v. H. F. Mooney, Jr.,
Superintendent, West Virginia Department of Public Safety, et al.
Appeal from the Circuit Court of Kanawha County, West Virginia. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 85-1823. Lowell M. Stroom, Appellant v. James E. Carter,
former President of the United States, et al. Appeal from the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 85-6669. John F. Keane, Appellant v. Gordon M. Ambach.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 85-6670. Suido M. D'Arezzo, Appellant v. Estate of Catherine
Christy, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Rhode Island. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 85-6709. Jon J. Arnold, Appellant v. South Dakota. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of South Dakota. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 85-1714. Kenneth Payne and Margaret Payne, Appellants v.
Larry Mount, Sheriff, Whatcom County, Washington, et al. Appeal
from the Court of Appeal of Washington, Division 1. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction.

674
MONDAY, JUNE 2, 1986
No. 85-6521. William J. Campbell, Appellant v. Michael R. Griffin,
District Judge, First Judicial District Court of Nevada, Carson City.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Nevada. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 85-6687. Ricardo Acen, Jr., and Alberto Penabriel, Appellants
v. Massachusetts. Appeal from the Supreme Judicial Court of Massa-
chusetts. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. —. Gustavo Manrique-Fernandez, Petitioner v. Immigration
and Naturalization Service. The motion to direct the Clerk to file the
petition for a writ of certiorari, out-of-time, is denied.
No. —. Robert K. Grace, Petitioner v. Heartland Transportation
Co. The motion for reconsideration of the order of Court entered March
3, 1986 is denied.
No. D-546. In the Matter of Disbarment of Irving A. August. Irving
A. August, of Birmingham, Michigan, having requested to resign as a
member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken
from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this
Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on February 24,
1986, is hereby discharged.
No. D-549. In the Matter of Disbarment of Charles Louis Duke.
Charles Louis Duke, of Houston, Texas, having requested to resign as
a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be
stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar
of this Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on March 24,
1986, is hereby discharged.
No. D-552. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard J. Plaza. Disbar-
ment order entered.

for divided argument is granted.
No. 85-495. Ansonia Board of Education, et al., Petitioners v. Ron-
ald Philbrook, et al. The motion of respondents Ansonia Federation of

675

No. 85-1388. Carrie Rose, etc., Petitioner v. Arkansas State Police.

No. 85-6698. Lorraine Allen Cappiello, Petitioner v. Anthony E.
Cappiello. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris is denied. Petitioner is allowed until June 23, 1986, within which
to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition
in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens, dissenting:
For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928
(1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without
reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 85-6768. Carlos Ramirez, Jr., Petitioner v. United States. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Petitioner is allowed until June 23, 1986, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of the Court. Justice Brennan, Justice
Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens dissenting: For the
reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928-(1983),
we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the
merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 85-6769. James A. Mc Neair, Petitioner v. Georgetown Univer-
sity Hospital. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until June 23, 1986, within
which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a
petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice
Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens, dis-
senting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464
U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari

676
MONDAY, JUNE 2, 1986
without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma
pauperis.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED

lants v. Florida Power Corporation, et al.; and
No. 85-1660. Group W Cable, Inc., et al., Appellants v. Florida
Power Corporation, et al. Appeals from the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. In these cases probable jurisdiction is
noted. The cases are consolidated and a total of one hour is allotted for
oral argument.
CERTIORARI GRANTED

Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Third Circuit granted.

Neighbors in Action, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted limited to
Question 1 presented by the petition.
No. 85-1222. Interstate Commerce Commission, Petitioner v. Texas,
et al.; and
No. 85-1267. Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad Company, et al.,
Petitioners v. Texas et al. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted. The cases are
consolidated and a total of one hour is allotted for oral argument.
No. 85-1239. Amoco Production Company, et al., Petitioners v. Vil-
lage of Gambell, Alaska, et al.; and
No. 85-1406. Donald P. Hodel, Secretary of the Interior, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Village of Gambell, et al. Petitions for writs of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.
The cases are consolidated and a total of one hour is allotted for oral
argument.
No. 85-1563. California, Petitioner v. Alvert Greenwood Brown, Jr.
The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Califor-
nia is granted limited to Question 1 presented by the petition.
No. 85-5221. Randall Lamont Griffith, Petitioner v. Kentucky. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
The petition for a writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Kentucky
is granted limited to the following question: In cases pending on direct

MONDAY, JUNE 2, 1986
677
appeal, should the holding in Batson v. Kentucky, No. 84-6263, be
given retroactive effect? The case is set for oral argument in tandem
with No. 85-5731, Brown v. United States.
No. 85-5731. Willie Davis Brown, aka Will Brown, Petitioner v.
United States. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari to the Untied
States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit is granted limited to the
following question: In cases pending on direct appeal, should the hold-
ing in Batson v. Kentucky, No. 84-6263 be given retroactive effect?
The case is set for oral argument in tandem with No. 85-5221, Griffith
v. Kentucky.
CERTIORARI DENIED

No. 84-782. South Carolina, et al., Petitioners v. Catewba Indian
Tribe of South Carolina. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom Justice Marshall and Justice
O'Connor join.
No. 85-390. City of Los Angeles and Department of Water and
Power, Petitioners v. Preferred Communications, Inc. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Judgment affirmed and case remanded to the United States District
Court for the Central District of California so that petitioners may file
an answer and the material factual disputes between the parties may be
resolved and for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
the Court. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Concurring opinion by Jus-
tice Blackmun with whom Justice Marshall and Justice O'Connor join.
No. 84-1923. Otis R. Bowen, Secretary of Health and Human Serv-
ices, et al., Petitioners v. City of New York, et al. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Justice Powell. Announced by Justice White.
No. 84-1809. Federal Trade Commission, Petitioner v. Indiana
Federation of Dentists. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court

690
MONDAY, JUNE 2, 1986
of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, JUNE 3, 1986
699
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Justice Brennan, Justice White, Justice Marshall, Justice
Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 85-554. United States, Petitioner v. Hughes Properties, Inc. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Stevens with whom the Chief Justice joins.
No. 84-1944. United States, et al., Appellants v. Alvin Hemme, et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern District
of Illinois. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States
District Court for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Justice Marshall.
No. 84-2030. Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation, Appellant v.
New York State Liquor Authority. Appeal from the Court of Appeals
of New York. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Marshall. Concurring opinion by Justice
Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice
White and Justice Rehnquist join. Justice Brennan took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 84-6807. Millie R. Lee, Petitioner v. Illinois. On writ of certio-
rari to the Appellate Court of Illinois, Fifth District. Judgment
reversed and cased remanded to the Appellate Court for further pro-
ceedings no inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom
the Chief Justice, Justice Powell and Justice Rehnquist join.
Adjourned until Monday, June 9, 1986 at 10 o'clock.
=



(JOURNAL)
SUNDAY, JUNE 8, 1986
701
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-950. Rudy Ramos Esquivel, Applicant v. O. L. McCotter,
Director, Texas Department of Corrections. The application for stay of
execution of the sentence of death presented to Justice White and by
him referred to the Court is denied. Dissenting statement by Justice
Brennan and Justice Marshall.

?

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 9, 1986
703
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Justice White, Justice Blackmun, Justice Rehnquist, Jus-
tice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
Justice White said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by me, filed with the
Clerk, and will not be announced orally.'
"
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-623. Cincinnati Bell Telephone Company, Appellant v. Public
Utilities Commission of Ohio, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Ohio. The motion of GTE Service Corporation for leave to file a brief as
amicus curiae is granted. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question. Justice Powell and Justice O'Connor took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion and this case.
No. 84-870. Louisiana Public Service Commission, et al., Appellants
v. South Central Bell Telephone Company. Appeal from the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of Public
Service Commission of Maryland v. Chesapeake and Potomac Tele-
phone Company of Maryland, 476 U.S. (1986). Justice Powell and
Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
-
No. 85-132. Alvin Hemme, et al., Appellants v. United States, et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern District
of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 85-1644. Roy P. Briehler, Appellant v. Poseidon Venture, Inc.,
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Rhode Island. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 85-6727. Donald A. Valway and Edith H. Valway, Appellants v.
Roger Burlingame. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New Hamp-
shire. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.

704
MONDAY, JUNE 9, 1986
No. 85-1689. Anthony L. Ginocchi, Appellant v. Burrell School Dis-
trict. Appeal from the Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 85-6742. Marjorie Johnston, Appellant v. Richard V. Perrott.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Vermont. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a properly presented federal question.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-483. Arkansas Public Service Commission, et al., Petitioners
v. Southwestern Bell Telephone Company. On petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.
The motion of National Association of Regulatory Utility Commission-
ers, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. The peti-
tion for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the
case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit for further consideration in light of Public Service Com-
mision of Maryland v. Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company
of Maryland, 476 U.S. _ (1986). Justice Powell and Justice O'Connor
took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion and this case.
No. 85-55. Otis R. Bowen, Secretary, Department of Health and
Human Services, Petitioner v. Lorraine Polaski, et al. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eighth Circuit for further consideration in light of Bowen v.
City of New York, 476 U.S. (1986).
No. 85-474. Patrick M. Hyatt, et al., Petitioners v. Otis R. Bowen,
Secretary, United States Department of Health and Human Services,
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of Bowen v. City of New York, 476 U.S. (1986).
No. 85-6553. Sammy Gibson and Norman Bonds, Petitioners v. Illi-
nois. On writ of certiorari to the Appellate Court of Illinois, First
District. The motion of petitioner Norman Bonds for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for a writ of certiorari as
to Norman Bonds is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, for further
consideration in light of Lee v. Illinois, 476 U.S. (1986). The peti-
tion for a writ of certiorari as to Sammy Gibson is denied.
--

MONDAY, JUNE 9, 1986
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
705
No. A-901. Theron K. Carter, et al., Petitioner v. Farm Bureau
Services, Inc. The application for stay addressed to Justice Brennan
and referred to the Court is denied.
No. A-907. Jack Lynn Hoffart, Applicant v. Texas. The application
for stay addressed to the Chief Justice and referred to the Court is
denied.
No. A-919. James A. Miller, Applicant v. Idaho. The application for
stay addressed to Justice Brennan and referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-542. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert William Bowles,
Jr. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-548. In the Matter of Disbarment of John Harrison Marble.
Disbarment order entered.
No. 85-99. Messerschmitt Bolkow Blohm, GmbH., Petitioner v. Vir-
ginia Walker, et al. The order entered April 21, 1986 granting the
petition for a writ of certiorari is vacated.
No. 85-6836. Carlos A. Gutierrez, Petitioner v. Office of Personnel
Management. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until June 30, 1986, within
which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a
petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice
Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens, dis-
senting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464
U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari
without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma
pauperis.
APPEAL JURISDICTION POSTPONED
No. 85-1708. California, et al., Appellants v. Cabazon Band of Mis-
sion Indians, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. Further consideration of the question of jurisdiction
is postponed to the hearing of the case on the merits.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 85-1695. Societe Nationale Industrielle Aerospatiale and Societe
de Construction d'Avions de Tourism, Petitioners v. United States Dis-
trict Court for the Southern District of Iowa. Petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit
granted.

No. 85-6756. James Ernest Hitchcock, Petitioner v. Louie L. Wain-

by the petition.

No. 84-900. New England Telephone and Telegraph Company, Peti-
tioner v. Public Utilities Commission of Maine, et al. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit
denied. Justice Powell and Justice O'Connor took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this petition.
No. 85-1544. Burlington Northern, Inc., Petitioner v. Jack D.
Anderson. The motion of Association of American Railroads, et al. for
leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Montana denied.
No. 85-1629. International Molders and Allied Workers Union,
AFL-CIO, et al., Petitioners v. James Howard and Robert Bates, etc.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eleventh Circuit denied. Justice Brennan, Justice White and
Justice Marshall would grant certiorari.
No. 85-1641. Linda Mulligan, Petitioner v. Francis Hazard, et al.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice White with
whom Justice Marshall joins.
No. 85-1710. Mallinckrodt, Inc., Petitioner v. Samuel F. Bennett,
et al. The motion of Syncor International Corporation for leave to file a
brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of American College of
Radiology for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The
motion of Society of Nuclear Medicine, et al. for leave to file a brief as
amici curiae is granted. The motion of American College of Nuclear
Physicians for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The
motion of petitioner to defer consideration of the petition for certiorari
is denied. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of
Missouri, Eastern District, denied. Justice White, Justice Marshall and
Justice O'Connor would grant certiorari.
No. 85-5555. Alvin R. Moore, Jr., Petitioner v. Frank Blackburn,
Warden. The petition for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit is denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Marshall with whom Justice Brennan joins.
No. 85-5868. David Mapes, Petitioner v. Ohio. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Ohio denied. Dissenting statement
by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.
No. 85-5886. Sterling Rault, Sr., Petitioner v. Louisiana. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit denied. Dissenting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice
Marshall.

petitions for rehearing are denied.

et al. The motion for leave to file a petition for rehearing is denied.

OPINIONS
No. 85-5238. Major Crane, Petitioner v. Kentucky. On writ of certio-
rari to the Supreme Court of Kentucky. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Supreme Court for further proceedings not inconsist-
ent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor.
No. 85-225. Otis R. Bowen, Secretary of Health and Human Serv-
ices, et al., Petitioners v. Michigan Academy of Family Physicians,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Justice
Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 84-1529. Otis R. Bowen, Secretary of Health and Human Serv-
ices, Petitioner v. American Hospital Association, et al. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Justice Stevens announced the judgment of the
Court and delivered an opinion in which Justice Marshall, Justice Black-
mun and Justice Powell joined. The Chief Justice concurs in the judg-
ment. Dissenting opinion by Justice White with whom Justice Brennan
joins and with whom Justice O'Connor joins as to Parts I, II, IV, and V.
Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor. Justice Rehnquist took no part
in the consideration or decision of this case.

TUESDAY, JUNE 10, 1986
723
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-959. Ralph Kemp, Warden, Applicant v. Roger Collins. The
application of the Attorney General of Georgia for an order to vacate
the stay of execution of sentence of death entered by the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit presented to Justice Powell
and by him referred to the Court is denied.



(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 11, 1986
725
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
85-755. Delynda Ann Ricker Barker Reed, Appellant v. Princess
Ann Ricker Campbell, Individually, and as Administratrix of the
Estate of Prince Rupert Ricker, Deceased. Appeal from the Court
of Appeals of Texas, Eighth Supreme Judicial District. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Stevens.
No. 85-546. United States, Petitioner v. Florence Blacketter Mottaz,
etc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun.
No. 84-495. Richard Thornburgh, et al., Appellants v. American Col-
lege of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, et al. Appeal from the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Appeal dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari granted. The judgment is affirmed. Justice Blackmun
delivered the opinion of the Court, in which Justice Brennan, Justice
Marshall, Justice Powell, and Justice Stevens joined. Concurring
opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by the Chief Justice.
Dissenting opinion by Justice White with whom Justice Rehnquist
joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor with whom Justice
Rehnquist joins.
No. 85-246. United States, Petitioner v. Dwight Dion, Sr. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.
Judgment reversed in part and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Marshall.
No. 84-780. Otis R. Bowen, Secretary of Health and Human Serv-
ices, et al., Appellants v. Stephen J. Roy, et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania. Judg-
ment vacated in part and case remanded to the District Court for fur-

726
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 11, 1986
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. The Chief
Justice announced the judgment of the Court and delivered and opinion
of the Court with respect to Parts I and II, and an opinion with respect
to Part III, in which Justice Powell and Justice Rehnquist join. Opinion
by Justice Blackmun concurring in part. Opinion by Justice Stevens
concurring in part and concurring in the result. Opinion by Justice
O'Connor concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom Jus-
tice Brennan and Justice Marshall join. Dissenting opinion by Justice
White.
Adjourned until Monday, June 16, 1986 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 16, 1986
727
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION ·
No. 84-1724. Richard A.. Snider and Margaret Q. Snider, Appellants
v. Virginia. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Virginia. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 85-1459. James H. Powell, Appellant v. Ruth Ann Powell.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Texas, Tenth Supreme Judicial
District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal ques-
tion. Justice White would postpone jurisdiction to the hearing of the
case on the merits.
No. 85-1754. Dennis Bober, et al., Appellants v. Walgreen Com-
pany, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice Brennan
would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral argument.
Justice White took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 85-279. American Petrofina Company of Texas, Petitioner v. Oil
Chemical & Atomic Workers International Union Local No. 4-23, et al.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light
of AT&T Technologies, Inc. v. Communications Workers of America,
475 U. S. (1986).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . Marvine Alice Comsia, Petitioner v. William A. Morris,
Judge. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certio-
rari, out-of-time, is denied.

728
MONDAY, JUNE 16, 1986
No. 84-1904. United States Department of the Treasury, Bureau of
Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, Appellant v. Anthony J. Galioto. The
motion of the Solicitor General for leave to file a supplemental brief
after argument is granted.
No. 85-1233. International Paper Company, Petitioner v. Harmel
Ouellette, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to partici-
pate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is
granted.
No. 85-1773. Charles M. Oberly, III and John E. Wilson, III, Appel-
lants v. Baltimore & Ohio Railroad Company, et al. The Solicitor Gen-
eral is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the
United States.
No. 85-1962. Paul R. Riddick, Jr., et al., Petitioners v. School Board
of City of Norfolk, et al. The application for an injunction presented to.
the Chief Justice and by him referred to the Court is denied. Justice
Marshall and Justice Blackmun would grant the application. Justice
Stevens would expedite consideration of the petition for a writ of certio-
rari and postpone action on the application pending such consideration.
No. 85-6878. Thomas Bruce Wilson, Petitioner v. United States. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Petitioner is allowed until July 7, 1986, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice
Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed
in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the
petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the
motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 85-7008. John Charles Lesko, Petitioner v. Pennsylvania. The
application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Jus-
tice Brennan and by him referred to the Court is granted pending the
disposition of the petition for writ of certiorari.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 85-1385. United States, Petitioner v. General Dynamics Corp.,
et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Federal Circuit granted.
No. 85-1581. Richard Solorio, Petitioner v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Military Appeals
granted.

Broadcasting and Cable, Inc. Petition for writ of certiorari to the

No. 85-1750. S/S Salvador, her engines, boilers, etc., et al., Petition-
ers v. Berisford Metals Corporation. The motion of Inter-American
Freight Conference for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.

curiae is granted. The motion of American President Lines, Ltd. for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit
denied. Justice White would grant certiorari.

writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas denied.

of mandamus is denied.

of mandamus and/or prohibition is denied.

No. 85-1447. Cabriolet Porsche + Audi, Inc., Petitioner v. American
Honda Motor Co., Inc.;
No. 85-1509. Ray E. Vintilla, et al., Petitioners v. United States
Steel Corporation Plan for Employee Pension Benefits;

Warden;
No. 85-5977. Edward Isley, Petitioner v. United States;
No. 85-6325. Samuel Bice Johnson, Petitioner v. Mississippi;
No. 85-6364. In Re Morris May, Petitioner;

Company;
No. 85-6517. In Re Zelma Frazier, Petitioner; and
No. 85-6524. Booker T. Washington, Jr., Petitioner v. Ron
Angelone, Warden, et al. The petitions for rehearing are denied.
No. 85-882. Albert J. Lovshin, Petitioner v. Department of the
Navy. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed further herein
in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for rehearing is denied.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Wednesday, June 18, 1986, until
Monday, June 23, 1986.

of this Court are granted.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, JUNE 17, 1986
749
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 85-568. Nantahala Power and Light Company, et al., Appellants
v. Lacy H. Thornburg, Attorney General of North Carolina, et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of North Carolina. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Supreme Court for further proceedings not
inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Con-
nor. Justice Powell and Justice Stevens took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this case.
No. 84-1948. Richard E. Lyng, Secretary of Agriculture, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Ronald E. Payne, et al., etc. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 85-664. Frank Young, Commissioner of Food and Drug Adminis-
tration, Petitioner v. Community Nutrition Institute, et al. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of
Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Stevens.
No. 84-1803. Attorney General of New York, Appellant v. Eduardo
Soto-Lopez, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Brennan.
Opinion by the Chief Justice concurring in the judgment. Opinion
by Justice White concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor with whom
Justice Rehnquist and Justice Stevens join.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.



(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 18, 1986
751
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist, and
Justice Stevens.
OPINIONS
No. 84-1839. Ronald A. Schiavone, Genaro Liquori and Joseph A.
DiCarolis, Petitioners v. Fortune, aka Time, Incorporated. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.
Judgments affirmed. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Stevens with whom the Chief Justice and Justice White join.
No. 84-902. Wardair Canada, Inc., Appellant v. Florida Department
of Revenue. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Opinion by the Chief Justice
concurring in part and concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Blackmun.
☑
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, JUNE 19, 1986
753
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 84-1979. Meritor Savings Bank, FSB, Petitioner v. Mechelle
Vinson, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment affirmed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist.
Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens. Opinion by Justice Marshall
concurring in the judgment with whom Justice Brennan, Justice Black-
mun and Justice Stevens join.
No. 85-215. Dynel McMillan, Lorna Peterson, James J. Dennison
and Harold L. Smalis, Petitioners v. Pennsylvania. On writ of certiorari
to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern District. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Marshall with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Blackmun join. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 85-521. Otis R. Bowen, Secretary of Health and Human Serv-
ices, et al., Appellants v. Public Agencies Opposed to Social Security
Entrapment, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Eastern District of California. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the District Court for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Powell.
☑
Adjourned until Monday, June 23, 1986 at 10 o'clock.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 23, 1986
755
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-922. Lineas Aereas Costarricenses, S.A., et al., Appellants v.
Florida Department of Revenue. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal ques-
tion. Justice Blackmun would note probable jurisdiction and set the
case for oral argument.
No. 84-1041. Air Jamaica Limited, et al., Appellants v. Florida
Department of Revenue. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Jus-
tice Blackmun would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral
argument.
No. 85-441. Lillian Roberts, Commissioner of Labor of the State of
New York, Appellant v. Burlington Industries, Inc.; and
No. 85-460. Irving Gilbert, et al., Appellants v. Burlington Indus-
tries, Inc. Appeals from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. The judgments are affirmed.
No. 85-944. John C. Brooks, Commissioner of Labor of the State of
North Carolina, Appellant v. Burlington Industries, Inc., et al. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. The
judgment is affirmed.
No. 85-1066. James G. Martin, Governor of the State of North Caro-
lina, et al., Appellants v. Terry L. Haith. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Eastern District of North Carolina. The
judgment is affirmed.
No. 85-1165. Nantahala Power and Light Company, et al., Appel-
lants v. Lacy H. Thornburg, Attorney General of North Carolina, et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of North Carolina. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the Supreme Court of North Caro-
lina for further consideration in light of Nantahala Power and Light

756
MONDAY, JUNE 23, 1986
Company v. Thornburg, 476 U.S. - (1986). Justice Powell and Jus-
tice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
-
.
No. 85-1307. Nantahala Power and Light Company, et al., Appel-
lants v. Lacy H. Thornburg, Attorney General of North Carolina, et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of North Carolina. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the Supreme Court of North Caro-
lina for further consideration in light of Nantahala Power and Light
Company v. Thornburg, 476 U.S. (1986). Justice Powell and Jus-
tice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 85-1690. Goodyear Farms, et al., Appellants v. City of Avon-
dale. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Arizona. The motion of Ari-
zona for leave to intervene is granted. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question. Justice Brennan and Justice White
would postpone further consideration of the question of jurisdiction to
the hearing of the case on the merits.
No. 85-1859. Martin A. Lundgard, Appellant v. Ohio. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Miami County. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 85-6850. William Edward Hardesty, Appellant v. Michigan.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Michigan. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 85-12. Pott Industries, Inc., Petitioner v. Ingram River Equip-
ment, Inc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of East River Steamship Corp. v. Transamerica
Delaval Inc., 476 U.S. (1986).
-
No. 85-406. George R. Ariyoshi, Governor of Hawaii, et al., Petition-
ers v. Selwyn A. Robinson, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Williamson County Regional Plan-
ning Commission v. Hamilton Bank of Johnson City, 473 U.S.
(1985).

MONDAY, JUNE 23, 1986
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
757
No. 85-1975. Earlene Polyak, Petitioner v. Frank Hulen and Wilma
Lesnansky. The application for an injunction addressed to the Chief
Justice and referred to the Court is denied.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 85-1798. Pennzoil Company, Appellant v. Texaco, Inc. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. In this
case probable jurisdiction is noted.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 85-998. United States, Petitioner v. Ronald Dale Dunn. The
motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit granted.
No. 85-1329. Gerald J. Young, George Cariste, Sol N. Klaymine and
Nathan Helfand, Petitioners v. United States, ex rel. Vuitton et Fils
S.A., et al.; and
No. 85-6207. Barry Dean Klayminc, Petitioner v. United States
ex rel. Vuitton et Fils S.A., Louis Vuitton S.A. The motion of peti-
tioner in No. 85-6207 for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
granted. The petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit are granted. The cases are consoli-
dated and a total of one hour is allotted for oral argument.
No. 85-1358. William L. Lukhard, Commissioner, Virginia Depart-
ment of Social Services, Petitioner v. Ona Mae Reed, et al. The motion
of respondents Reed, et al. for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit granted.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 84-1808. James White, dba Blue Wave Oyster Co., et al., Peti-
tioners v. M/V Testbank, etc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied.
No. 84–1966. CWT Farms, Inc., and CWT International, Inc., Peti-
tioners v. Commissioner of Internal Revenue. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit

OPINIONS
No. 85–202. Offshore Logistics, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Beth A.
Tallentire, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Opinion by Justice
Powell concurring in Part III and dissenting with whom Justice Bren-
nan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens join.
No. 85-5319. Willie Jasper Darden, Petitioner v. Louie L. Wain-
wright, Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit.
Judgment affirmed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice Powell. Concurring opinion by the Chief Justice. Dissenting

768
MONDAY, JUNE 23, 1986
opinion by Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun
with whom Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens join.
No. 85-632. Charles Atkins, Commissioner, Massachusetts Depart-
ment of Public Welfare, Petitioner v. Santos Rivera, et al. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Judicial Court for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Blackmun.
No. 85-62. Maine, Appellant v. Robert J. Taylor and United States.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 85-599. United States, Petitioner v. American Bar Endowment,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Federal Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals with instructions to reverse the judgment of the Claims Court
with respect to American Bar Endowment, and to affirm the judgment
of the Claims Court with respect to the individual taxpayers. Opinion
by Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens. Justice
Powell and Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this case.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, JUNE 24, 1986
771
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens and Justice O'Connor.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 85-7182. Jerome Bowden, Petitioner v. Ralph Kemp, Warden.
The application for stay of execution of the sentence of death presented
to Justice Powell and by him referred to the Court is denied. The peti-
tion for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eleventh Circuit is denied. Dissenting statement by Justice Bren-
nan and Justice Marshall.
Adjourned until Wednesday, June 25, 1986 at 10 o'clock.
=



(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 25, 1986
773
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 84-2015. MacDonald, Sommer & Frates, Appellant v. County of
Yolo, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Third Appel-
late Distict. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice White with whom the Chief Justice joins, with
whom Justice Powell and Justice Rehnquist join as to Parts I, II, and
III. Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist with whom Justice Powell
joins.
No. 85-198. Celotex Corporation, Petitioner v. Myrtle Neil Catrett,
Administratrix of the Estate of Louis H. Catrett, deceased. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of.
Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Opinion by Justice White concur-
ring in the Court's opinion and judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Brennan with whom the Chief Justice and Justice Blackmun join. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 85-410. Memphis Community School District, et al., Petitioners
v. Edward J. Stachura. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Powell. Justice Brennan and
Justice Stevens join the opinion of the Court and also join Justice
Marshall's opinion concurring in the judgment, post. Opinion by Justice
Marshall concurring in the judgment with whom Justice Brennan, Jus-
tice Blackmun, and Justice Stevens join.

reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-

Court with respect to Parts I, IV, and V, and an opinion with respect to
Parts II and III in which the Chief Justice, Justice Rehnquist, and
Justice O'Connor join. Concurring opinion by the Chief Justice.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall
joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.

ion of the Court with respect to Parts I and II and an opinion in parts

THURSDAY, JUNE 26, 1986
III, IV and V in which Justice Brennan, Justice Blackmun and Justice

which Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun joined
as to Parts I, III, and IV. Opinion by the Chief Justice concurring in
the judgment. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concurring in the judgment
with whom the Chief Justice and Justice Rehnquist join. Opinion by
Justice Powell concurring in Part II and dissenting with whom Justice
Stevens joins.

OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 85-1500. Roland V. Acosta, Petitioner v. Louisiana Department
of Health and Human Resources, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Respond-
ent's motion for award of damages on the ground that the petition is
frivolous is denied. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. Judg-
ment affirmed. Opinion per curiam. Justice Brennan would grant the
petition for certiorari and set the case for oral argument. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Marshall.
No. 85-6593. Earl Allen, Petitioner v. Stephen L. Hardy, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit. Petitioner's motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion per curiam. Justice Blackmun would grant the peti-
tion for a writ of certiorari and set the case for oral argument. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Justice Stevens joins.

·
MONDAY, JUNE 30, 1986
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
781
No. 85-6900. Willie H. Richardson, Appellant v. L.S.U. Medical
Center, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 84-1426. Robert Abrams, Attorney General of the State of New
York, Petitioner v. Michael McCray. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. The petition
for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit
for further consideration in light of Allen v. Hardy, 478 U.S.
(1986) and Batson v. Kentucky, 476 U.S.
(1986).
No. 85-97. Petroleum Helicopters, Inc., Petitioner v. Carol T.
Sincox, individually and as natural tutrix of the minors, Byron Sincox
and Darin J. Hebert. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Offshore Logistics, Inc. v. Tallentire, 477 U.S.
(1986).
No. 85-1028. Michigan, Petitioner v. Larry Booker. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma paupe-
ris is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light of Allen
v. Hardy, 478 U.S. (1986) and Batson v. Kentucky, 476 U.S.
(1986). Dissenting opinion by the Chief Justice.

denied.

ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-1011. Ralph Kemp, Warden, Applicant v. Son H. Fleming.
The application of the Attorney General of Georgia for an order to
vacate the stay of execution of sentence of death entered by the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit presented to Justice
Powell and by him referred to the Court is denied.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, JULY 1, 1986
803
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Justice Brennan, Justice White, Justice Marshall, Justice
Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, and
Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS

day Inn, Appellant v. Tourism Company of Puerto Rico, et al. Appeal

join.

join.

Judgment affirmed in part, vacated in part, and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Opinion by Justice Brennan

in part with whom Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Justice Ste-
vens join. Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring in part and dissent-
ing in part. Opinion by Justice Powell concurring in part and dissenting
in part with whom the Chief Justice and Justice Rehnquist join.

et al.; and

TUESDAY, JULY 1, 1986
No. 85-428. United States, et al., Petitioners v. William C. Friday,
et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for

No. 85-519. William C. Randall, Roger E. Austin, Tom W. Anderson
and Myrel A. Newmann, Petitioners v. B. J. Loftsgaarden, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Concurring opinion by Justice Blackmun.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan.
No. 85-117. A. G. Baker, Jr., et al., Appellants v. General Motors
Corporation and Michigan Employment Security Commission. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Michigan. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom
Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun join.
No. 85–434. United States, Petitioner v. Charlotte James, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with
whom Justice Marsall and Justice O'Connor join.
No. 84–1974. Jimmy C. Rose, Warden, Petitioner v. Stanley Barham
Clark. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Powell. Concurring opinion by the Chief Jus-
tice. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in the judgment. Dissenting

806
WEDNESDAY, JULY 2, 1986
opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom Justice Brennan and Justice
Marshall join.
No. 85-5. Pennsylvania, et al., Petitioners v. Delaware Valley Citi-
zens' Council for Clean Air, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed in
part, reversed in part, and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice White. Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring in part
and dissenting in part with whom Justice Marshall joins, and with
whom Justice Brennan joins as to Part II. An order will issue restoring
the case to the argument calendar insofar as it raises the question
whether attorney's fees chargeable to a losing defendant under the
Clean Water Act and the comparable statutes may be enhanced based
on the risk of loss, and if so, to what extent.
No. 84-1656. Local 28 of the Sheet Metal Workers' International
Association and Local 28 Joint Apprenticeship Committee, Petitioners
v. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, et al. On writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judg-
ment affirmed. Justice Brennan announced the judgment of the Court
and delivered the opinion of the Court with respect to Parts I, II, III,
and VI, and an opinion with respect to Parts IV, V, and VII in which
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, and Justice Stevens join. Opinion
by Justice Powell concurring in part and concurring in the judgment.
Opinion by Justice O'Connor concurring in part and dissenting in part.
Dissenting opinion by Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Rehnquist with whom the Chief Justice joins.
No. 84-1999. Local Number 93, International Association of Fire-
fighters, AFL-CIO, C.L.C., Petitioner v. City of Cleveland, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Concurring
opinion by Justice O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice White. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Rehnquist with whom the Chief Justice joins.
Adjourned until Monday, July 7, 1986 at 10 o'clock.

Dissenting opinion by Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Blackmun.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 85-532. Sports and Health Club Inc., dba St. Louis Park Sports
and Health Club, et al., Appellants v. Minnesota, etc. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Minnesota. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction.
No. 85-1170. Clarence P. Rappleyea, Appellant v. Hugh L. Carey,
et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice Stevens
would vacate the judgment and remand the case to the Court of
Appeals of New York for further consideration in light of Davis v.
Bandemer, 478 U.S. — (1986).
-
No. 85-1693. Charles A. Bowsher, Comptroller General of the
United States, et al., Appellants v. American Postal Workers Union,
AFL-CIO, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of Columbia. The judgment is affirmed.

No. D-553. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ray Velasquez. Disbar-
